Title: Harnessing AI for Small-Scale Irrigation Systems: A Comprehensive Literature Review
Affiliations: University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa; University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Monchusi, Bessie B., School of Engineering, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa; Kgopa, Alfred Thaga, School of Computing, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa; Mokwana, Tlhokaboyo Innocentia, School of Engineering, University of South Africa, Pretoria, South Africa
Abstract: This research paper investigates the critical role of small-scale irrigation systems, particularly for smallholder farmers, through an extensive literature review sourced from the Scopus database. The study focuses on the essential elements of smart irrigation systems and the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance water management efficiency and boost agricultural productivity. The methodology encompasses a thorough review of existing literature to pinpoint challenges and limitations in small-scale irrigation, proposing potential solutions to these issues. By examining case studies and discussing AI technology implementations, the paper underscores the potential for automating decision-making processes using real-Time data, which could lead to sustainable agricultural practices and improved crop yields. The findings illustrate how AI integration with innovative irrigation systems can transform traditional farming, enhancing efficiency and environmental sustainability. The discussion elaborates on the implications, advocating for further research and development to maximize the benefits of AI-driven irrigation for farmers worldwide. Recommendations include increased investment in AI technologies, knowledge sharing, and capacity building among smallholder farmers to adopt these advanced practices. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Riya; S.K., Mogha, Sandeep Kumar; Vatsal
Title: Smart Farming Solutions: Deep Learning-Driven Multi-Classification of Rice Crop Diseases
Affiliations: Chandigarh University, Mohali, India
Authors with affiliations: Riya, null, Department of Mathematics, Chandigarh University, Mohali, India; Mogha, Sandeep Kumar, Department of Mathematics, Chandigarh University, Mohali, India; Vatsal, null, Department of Mathematics, Chandigarh University, Mohali, India
Abstract: Rice, being recognized as a fundamental staple crop on a global scale, assumes a central position in ensuring food security worldwide. Nevertheless the agricultural sector encounters significant obstacles in the shape of many illnesses that possess the potential to cause severe damage to crop productivity and jeopardize the availability of food resources. The proposed work endeavors to undertake a thorough investigation to tackle these issues by creating a resilient system for detecting diseases and classifying rice plants into multiple categories. Rice farming is faced with several frequent illnesses, each possessing distinct characteristics and exerting a specific impact on the health of the crop. The diseases encompassing rice blast, rice blight, hispa disease, and rice stem rot disease are widely recognized for their significant capacity to case extensive harm. Differentiating these illnesses from healthy rice plants is a procedure that requires significant labor and is susceptible to errors when conducted manually. To address these problems, the suggested study has carefully assembled a dataset consisting of high-resolution photos of rice plants. These images encompass a range of growth phases and indications of diseases. By utilizing state-of-the-art deep learning (DL) methodologies, the proposed work developed an advanced image processing model that exhibits the ability to classify rice plants into five discrete categories: healthy, rice blast, rice blight, hispa disease, and rice stem rot disease, without the need for manual intervention. The presented research encompasses not only the construction of a precise classification model but also explores the practical consequences of early illness detection in the context of rice farming. The experimental findings yielded highly encouraging results, as our model had an exceptional accuracy rate of 97.21%. The practical implications of our research extend far beyond the boundaries of the laboratory. The implementation of precision agricultural techniques is crucial for the promotion of sustainable rice cultivation and the maintenance of food security in an era characterized by significant global transformations. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Mathias, Ajisha; J.R.F., Raj, J. Relin Francis; S.R., Raja, S. R.; R.S., Santhana Krishnan, R. Santhana; G., Balamuralikrishnan, G.; N., Soundiraraj, N.
Author full names: Mathias, Ajisha (57209369621); Raj, J. Relin Francis (57209462571); Raja, S. R. (59820087800); Santhana Krishnan, R. Santhana (57868354800); Balamuralikrishnan, G. (59511460800); Soundiraraj, N. (57193092662)
Title: AppleDiseaseNet-B7: A Robust Solution for Apple Leaf Disease Classification and Model Evaluation
Affiliations: Vel Tech Rangarajan Dr.Sagunthala R&D Institute of Science and Technology, Chennai, India; Saveetha School of Engineering, Chennai, India; Hindustan Institute of Technology and Science, Chennai, India; SCAD College of Engineering and Technology, Tirunelveli, India; Velammal College of Engineering and Technology, Madurai, India; PSNA College of Engineering and Technology, Dindigul, India
Authors with affiliations: Mathias, Ajisha, Vel Tech Rangarajan Dr.Sagunthala R&D Institute of Science and Technology, Chennai, India; Raj, J. Relin Francis, Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Saveetha School of Engineering, Chennai, India; Raja, S. R., Hindustan Institute of Technology and Science, Chennai, India; Santhana Krishnan, R. Santhana, Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, SCAD College of Engineering and Technology, Tirunelveli, India; Balamuralikrishnan, G., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Velammal College of Engineering and Technology, Madurai, India; Soundiraraj, N., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, PSNA College of Engineering and Technology, Dindigul, India
Abstract: Apple leaf diseases, like cedar apple rust, black rot, and apple scab, pose severe obstacles to apple farming and impact crop productivity and quality. The sophisticated classification model AppleDiseaseNet-B7, known for its efficiency and outstanding performance, was created using the EfficientNetB7 architecture and is presented in this paper. The model improves its feature extraction capabilities by utilizing pretrained weights from ImageNet, which makes it a good fit for differentiating between various apple leaf diseases. AppleDiseaseNet-B7 incorporates numerous unique layers intended to increase classification precision. A Global Average Pooling layer streamlines feature maps, complicated patterns are captured by a dense layer with ReLU activation, overfitting is reduced by a dropout layer, and class prediction is accomplished by a final dense layer with softmax activation. The model's resilience is further increased using thorough data preparation, and augmentation approaches from the PlantVillage and Kaggle Apple Leaf Disease datasets. A comprehensive comparison is made between AppleDiseaseNet-B7's performance and other well-known models, including DenseNet121, ResNet50, and AlexNet. The analysis shows that AppleDiseaseNet-B7 regularly performs better than comparable models in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score, among other criteria. This comparison demonstrates how well AppleDiseaseNet-B7 performs in classifying apple leaf diseases, providing a reliable and effective method for managing and detecting agricultural diseases. The study emphasizes how crucial sophisticated model selection is to enhancing crop health monitoring and disease control. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Mishra, Trapti; P.S., Nair, Pramod S.
Author full names: Mishra, Trapti (57193435076); Nair, Pramod S. (57188750064)
Title: Predictive Analytics in Agriculture: Machine Learning for Farm Suitability Evaluation
Affiliations: Medic-Caps University, India
Authors with affiliations: Mishra, Trapti, Department of Computer Science, Medic-Caps University, India; Nair, Pramod S., Department of Computer Science, Medic-Caps University, India
Abstract: Given the rapid increase in global population, advancements in agricultural technology are crucial for ensuring food security and promoting sustainable farming practices. The study suggests a new way to determine whether a farm is suitable for a given crop by combining several machine learning algorithms, namely Restricted Boltzmann Machines, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks (RBMs). Our objective is to combine these models so that we can better understand the patterns in agricultural data that are influenced by multiple variables, including weather, soil, crop yields, and other environmental factors. For the purpose of handling consecutive data and predicting future climatic trends that affect farming suitability, our long short-term memory (LSTM) model is designed. By expertly analysing patterns in satellite pictures and other spatial data, the CNN component assesses land qualities. Lastly, important factors influencing agricultural production are extracted using the RBM's feature learning abilities. Our integrated model was trained using a massive dataset collected from various agro-climatic zones. How well the model projected, given both present and future conditions, whether a plot of land would be appropriate for a specific crop was used to evaluate its effectiveness. The results demonstrate that our technique can reliably forecast which farms would be the best fit. Additionally, our model can assist lawmakers and farmers in making educated decisions regarding crop rotation, land usage, and operational management. A paradigm shift in precision agriculture could result from this. This research has the potential to improve crop yield, sustainability, and resilience to climate change by pushing the development of intelligent agricultural systems forward. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Dutta, Chiranjit; S., Moudgil, Suveg; S., Aluvala, Srinivas; V.R., Saxena, Virat Raj; K., Devi, K.; J., Singh, Jagendra
Author full names: Dutta, Chiranjit (56810841600); Moudgil, Suveg (58558750900); Aluvala, Srinivas (46160933400); Saxena, Virat Raj (58984261900); Devi, K. (59109750900); Singh, Jagendra (56347348900)
Title: Real-Time Crop Monitoring System Using Deep Learning Techniques for Increasing Production
Affiliations: SRM Institute of Science and Technology, NCR Campus, Ghaziabad, India; Galgotias University, Greater Noida, India; SR University, Warangal, India; Raj Kumar Goel institute of Technology, Ghaziabad, India; DAV Autonomous College, Commerce, India; Bennett University, Greater Noida, India
Authors with affiliations: Dutta, Chiranjit, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, NCR Campus, Ghaziabad, India; Moudgil, Suveg, School of Computing Science and Engineering, Galgotias University, Greater Noida, India; Aluvala, Srinivas, School of Computer Science & Artificial Intelligence, SR University, Warangal, India; Saxena, Virat Raj, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Raj Kumar Goel institute of Technology, Ghaziabad, India; Devi, K., Department of Commerce, DAV Autonomous College, Commerce, India; Singh, Jagendra, School of Computer Science Engineering and Technology, Bennett University, Greater Noida, India
Abstract: This study applies machine learning to determine rice crop production using sensor information from temperature, humidity, and water levels. This project looks forward to providing insights to maximize agricultural practices and allow data-driven decision-making in rice cultivation. This is in line with how well these disparate machine learning models can predict rice crop production when measured against precision, accuracy, recall, and F1 score. To some extent, this is evident, as this study found that the machine learning models can predict yield quite satisfactorily, of which the model Random Forest performs very well in terms of precision and accuracy. Among them were the exactitude of sensor data and the algorithm selection, along with subsequent model assessment, refinement, and the ingression of great datasets inclusive of a broader set of environmental characteristics and crop yields - that were considered to be crucial in improving the precision of yield prediction algorithms. Additionally, the use of machine learning in farming has a number of benefits, such as enabling farmers to make decisions about crop management, irrigation, and optimization of yield. Combining machine learning methodologies with sensor technology can optimize resource allocation, save water, and improve overall agricultural productivity. Further, this study will facilitate the implementation of smart irrigation systems and set the stage for data-driven decision-making in agriculture for better farming practices and food production worldwide. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Gyani, Divyangini; D., Ghosh, Debomita; Sonal; T., Ghose, Tirthadip
Author full names: Gyani, Divyangini (58143868800); Ghosh, Debomita (55835383600); Sonal (57215656924); Ghose, Tirthadip (7006826923)
Title: IoT-Enabled Monitoring and Forecasting for Sustainable Adaptive Irrigation System using CatBoost Algorithm
Affiliations: Birla Institute of Technology, Mesra, Ranchi, India; Birla Institute of Technology, Sindri, India
Authors with affiliations: Gyani, Divyangini, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology, Mesra, Ranchi, India; Ghosh, Debomita, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology, Mesra, Ranchi, India; Sonal, null, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology, Sindri, India; Ghose, Tirthadip, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology, Mesra, Ranchi, India
Abstract: Agriculture is essential for the expansion of sustainable development. It is the backbone of the global economy, and its success is contingent primarily on the availability of water. The growing population in coming decades is probably going to boost this demand. It is a must to use new strategies that optimizes the water quantity required for irrigation in order to meet this sustainable demand. However, only watering is not sufficient for optimal plant growth. For overall plant health monitoring a data monitoring and estimation for approximating the plant growth is required. With the aid of global and local control, crop productivity can be made and adaptive soil moisture (SM) prediction model can control the required water and nutrients to be supplied to it. Developing the perfect model for SM prediction can be difficult, though, because of the many structural features and climatic variables involved. This work presents an internet of things (IoT) database creation facility and soil moisture forecasting facility using CatBoost algorithm. The IoT integrated sensors are used to monitor the parameters needed for optimal plant health and growth whereas the forecasting model is required for an adaptive irrigation system and increase crop yield to sustain an ever-growing economy. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Kumar, Ayush; H.K., Upadhay, Harsh Kumar; J.N.M., Iqubal, Jawid Nazir Mohamed
Author full names: Kumar, Ayush (58367256900); Upadhay, Harsh Kumar (59425225300); Iqubal, Jawid Nazir Mohamed (59425800800)
Title: SMART FARMING SYSTEM: Enhancing Water Efficiency, Automated Care, and Disease Detection Using IoT and CNN
Source title: Advances in Science and Engineering Technology International Conferences, ASET
Affiliations: Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Dubai Campus, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, Ayush, School of Engineering and IT, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Dubai Campus, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Upadhay, Harsh Kumar, School of Engineering and IT, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Dubai Campus, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Iqubal, Jawid Nazir Mohamed, School of Engineering and IT, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Dubai Campus, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The International Water Management Institute states that because of insufficient or excessive water supplies, inefficient irrigation techniques can result in crop output reductions of up to 30%. Inadequate irrigation practices can lead to waterlogging and salt problems on up to 25% of the irrigated land area worldwide. In addition to automatic watering, this study presents a smart farming system designed specifically for Neon Pothos that uses convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for disease detection and real-time monitoring. Neon Pothos' specific requirements are met by the system for this experimental procedure, which makes use of a NodeMCU ESP-12E (8266) microprocessor, a high-precision moisture sensor, and a DHT22 temperature/humidity sensor. CNN makes problem identification simple and efficient to identify diseases. Through a dashboard on a mobile application, users may keep an eye on various parameters and receive push notifications for illness and irrigation alerts. Ad hoc watering is made possible via manual pump control, and powerful algorithms that use the system's database to analyze disease prevalence and water use improve watering plans. This system, which combines technology, algorithms, and user-centered design to promote sustainable farming habits, helps preserve water resources and promotes environmental health. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Data-Driven Decisions: A Review of Machine Learning Models, Soil Sensors and Crop Recommendation Systems
Affiliations: Vallurupalli Nageswara Rao Vignana Jyothi Institute of Engineering & Technology, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Nagaraju, G., Department of Computer Science and Engineering (AIML & IoT), Vallurupalli Nageswara Rao Vignana Jyothi Institute of Engineering & Technology, Hyderabad, India; Rishika, Nayakoti, Department of Computer Science and Engineering (AIML & IoT), Vallurupalli Nageswara Rao Vignana Jyothi Institute of Engineering & Technology, Hyderabad, India; Pranav, Paruchuri, Department of Computer Science and Engineering (AIML & IoT), Vallurupalli Nageswara Rao Vignana Jyothi Institute of Engineering & Technology, Hyderabad, India; Mukesh, Pothala, Department of Computer Science and Engineering (AIML & IoT), Vallurupalli Nageswara Rao Vignana Jyothi Institute of Engineering & Technology, Hyderabad, India; Anthyush, Talluri, Department of Computer Science and Engineering (AIML & IoT), Vallurupalli Nageswara Rao Vignana Jyothi Institute of Engineering & Technology, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: The integration of advanced technologies in revolutionary agriculture transformed decision-making processes through the implementation of data-driven techniques. This study presents a thorough examination of the connection of machine learning models, soil sensors, and crop recommendation systems, with the purpose of demonstrating their combined impact on agricultural practices. The research delves into the crucial role of machine learning algorithms in agricultural data collecting, highlighting their ability to analyze complex datasets and derive helpful insights for informed decision-making. Furthermore, this paper explores the ever-evolving environment of soil-sensing technologies, emphasizing their significance to precision agriculture by providing real-time, high-resolution data on soil conditions. In addition, crop recommendation integration into systems is investigated, with a focus on its effectiveness in improving crop choices based on data-driven insights acquired from historical and real-time data. The combination of these technical aspects has been identified as a turning point in the development of sustainable agriculture. Embracing these advances in technology not only makes agriculture more efficient, but also accounts for a more resilient and environmentally conscientious future, demonstrating the transformative potential of data-driven techniques in influencing the trajectory of global food supply. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Santhosh, B. J. (59410287400); Balarengadurai, C. (57204777085)
Title: Edge-AI based Plant Leaf Disease Identification and Prevention for Smart Agriculture
Affiliations: Vidyavardhaka College of Engineering, Mysore, Mysore, India; Visvesvaraya Technological University, Belagavi, India
Authors with affiliations: Santhosh, B. J., Department of CSE, Vidyavardhaka College of Engineering, Mysore, Mysore, India, Visvesvaraya Technological University, Belagavi, India; Balarengadurai, C., Department of CSE, Vidyavardhaka College of Engineering, Mysore, Mysore, India, Visvesvaraya Technological University, Belagavi, India
Abstract: Smart agriculture has surfaced as a revolutionary method to enhance crop productivity and sustainability.One critical aspect of this paradigm is the integration of Edge-Artificial Intelligence (Edge-AI) for efficient plant disease identification and prevention.This study investigates the latest developments in employing Edge-AI techniques for the control of plant leaf diseases in smart agriculture.The article commences by providing a synopsis of the challenges posed by plant diseases in agriculture and their potential implications for global food security.It underscores the necessity for proactive identification of diseases and prevention strategies to mitigate these challenges.The survey then delves into the integration of Edge-AI technologies at the edge of the agricultural ecosystem, enabling real-time processing and decision-making.The analysis encompasses a thorough examination of diverse Edge-AI models and algorithms utilized for identifying plant leaf diseases, highlighting both their strengths and limitations.Principal techniques, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), and ensemble learning methods are emphasized in the context of their effectiveness in identifying diverse types of plant diseases.The survey highlights the importance of edge computing in enabling localized processing and decision-making, reducing latency and dependency on centralized systems.It explores the integration of sensor networks, Internet of Things (IoT) devices, and Edge-AI in creating a robust and responsive smart agriculture ecosystem.The paper also addresses challenges and open research issues in the field, including data privacy concerns, model robustness, and the need for standardized datasets.Additionally, it discusses emerging trends such as federated learning and blockchain for secure and collaborative disease management.This study offers an extensive overview of the cutting-edge Edge-AI technologies for identifying and preventing plant leaf diseases in smart agriculture.By comprehending the present landscape and anticipating future directions, researchers and practitioners can make informed decisions to create scalable and efficient solutions for sustainable and resilient agricultural systems. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Gacek, Wiktor (59407323700); Tulczyjew, Łukasz (57215653467); Wijata, Agata M. (57015460700); Longépé, Nicolas (23492895800); Le Saux, Bertrand (6506307016); Nalepa, Jakub (55441340400)
Title: ESTIMATING SOIL PARAMETERS FROM HYPERSPECTRAL IMAGES USING ENSEMBLES OF CLASSIC AND DEEP MACHINE LEARNING MODELS
Source title: International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS)
Affiliations: Silesian University of Technology, Gliwice, Poland; KP Labs, Gliwice, Poland; European Space Agency Φ-Lab, Frascati, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Gacek, Wiktor, Silesian University of Technology, Gliwice, Poland; Tulczyjew, Łukasz, Silesian University of Technology, Gliwice, Poland, KP Labs, Gliwice, Poland; Wijata, Agata M., Silesian University of Technology, Gliwice, Poland, KP Labs, Gliwice, Poland; Longépé, Nicolas, European Space Agency Φ-Lab, Frascati, Italy; Le Saux, Bertrand, European Space Agency Φ-Lab, Frascati, Italy; Nalepa, Jakub, Silesian University of Technology, Gliwice, Poland, KP Labs, Gliwice, Poland
Abstract: Recent advances in remote sensing and artificial intelligence offer exciting opportunities in an array of fields, with precision agriculture being a notable use case. Here, estimating soil parameters from remotely-sensed hyperspectral imagery at a global scale can play a pivotal role in day-to-day operations, as it may help optimize agricultural management processes, hence positively affecting our planet. In this paper, we tackled the problem of estimating soil parameters from hyperspectral images and introduced heterogeneous regression ensembles for this task. They not only benefit from both classic and deep machine learning models but were also thoroughly investigated and fine-tuned in our rigorous experimental study, performed over a well-established HYPERVIEW benchmark dataset. The experiments showed that such heterogeneous ensembles outperform other techniques and offer a high level of model flexibility. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: P., Bai, Peng; Y., Xia, Ying; J., Feng, Jiangfan
Title: Composite Perception and Multiscale Fusion Network for Arbitrary-Oriented Object Detection in Remote Sensing Imagery
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
Affiliations: Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Chongqing, China
Authors with affiliations: Bai, Peng, School of Computer Science and Technology, Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Chongqing, China; Xia, Ying, School of Computer Science and Technology, Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Chongqing, China; Feng, Jiangfan, School of Computer Science and Technology, Chongqing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Chongqing, China
Abstract: Arbitrary-oriented object detection has been widely used in remote sensing image object detection, mainly benefiting from accurate boundary boxes with less background information. However, the fixed receptive field feature extraction adopted by current mainstream methods limits the dynamic focusing ability of the model, resulting in insufficient context information capture, which leads to small object submergence. Furthermore, the complex background and dense distribution of objects in remote sensing images also increase the difficulty of detection, making it vulnerable to noise and fuzzy boundary interference. Therefore, we propose a new arbitrary-oriented object detection (AOOD) network called composite perception and multiscale fusion network (CPMFNet). First, to aggregate different levels of context information of the object and effectively enhance the context modeling ability of the detector, we propose an adaptive spatial perception module (ASPM) and insert it into the residual network as a plug-and-play module to realize dynamic receptive field convolution. Second, we redesigned a feature pyramid network (FPN) equipped with a composite perception and context integration module (CPCIM) and detail noise balance filter (DNBF). CPCIM realizes cross-scale feature fusion, mines position and detail features of shallow networks, enhances global semantic expression, and weakens interference of background information. DNBF can effectively suppress the interference of noise and fuzzy boundaries and guide deep networks to alleviate the inundation of small objects. Experiments on four remote sensing benchmark datasets (DOTA-v1.0, DOTA-v1.5, DIOR-R, and HRSC2016) show that CPMFNet (ours) achieves SOTA performance, in which the mean average precision (mAP) is 78.23% on the DOTA-v1.0 dataset, 70.85% on the DOTA-v1.5 dataset, and 67.58% and 98.61% on the DIOR-R and HRSC2016 datasets, respectively. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Anwar, Batool; M.M., Morsey, Mohamed Mabrouk; I.M., Hegazy, Islam M.; Z.T., Fayed, Zaki Taha; T.I.B., El-Arif, Taha Ibrahim B.
Author full names: Anwar, Batool (59388452100); Morsey, Mohamed Mabrouk (53980148300); Hegazy, Islam M. (9272098500); Fayed, Zaki Taha (6506016527); El-Arif, Taha Ibrahim B. (56109321000)
Title: Toward Precision Agriculture: Integrating Machine Learning Techniques for Smart Farming Systems
Affiliations: Faculty of Computer and Information Sciences, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Anwar, Batool, Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Computer and Information Sciences, Cairo, Egypt; Morsey, Mohamed Mabrouk, Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Computer and Information Sciences, Cairo, Egypt; Hegazy, Islam M., Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Computer and Information Sciences, Cairo, Egypt; Fayed, Zaki Taha, Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Computer and Information Sciences, Cairo, Egypt; El-Arif, Taha Ibrahim B., Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Computer and Information Sciences, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Smart agriculture holds a transformative potential, driven by cutting-edge technologies, in revolutionizing the global food production sector and enhancing food safety measures. This is achieved by leveraging the capabilities of smart maps, artificial intelligence, and agricultural data analytics. Hence, farmers can benefit from it as it allows them to streamline resource utilization. This, in turn, leads to reduced inputs of fertilizers, labor, seeds, and water, while simultaneously amplifying crops. Therefore, this paper introduces a comprehensive system for advancing smart map agriculture, comprising five pivotal stages designed to yield accurate and meaningful results. Notable progress is achieved through meticulous data acquisition by employing the rice seedling and WeedNet datasets, coupled with feature extraction utilizing the MobileNet architecture. The classification stage is critical for distinguishing between rice and land in the first dataset and between crops and weeds in the second one. It further enhances the system's efficacy. Additionally, segmentation using K-means clustering to detect rice or crop is employed. Notably, the current approach exhibits promising performance levels. It results in 99.7%, 100%, 99.4%, and 99.72% for accuracy, precision, recall, and F1_score, respectively, in the rice seedling dataset, as well as achieving 98.72%, 97.3%, 100%, and 98.63% in the WeedNet dataset. The primary contribution of this study lies in the integration of MobileNet and SVM architectures for feature extraction and classification in the agriculture field. It also presents the innovative use of K-means clustering for segmenting agricultural fields. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Kaur, Arshleen; R., Sharma, Rishabh; S., Chattopadhyay, Saumitra; K., Joshi, Kireet
Author full names: Kaur, Arshleen (58195664300); Sharma, Rishabh (57220725633); Chattopadhyay, Saumitra (57268881400); Joshi, Kireet (57210754758)
Title: Cotton Leaf Disease Classification Using Fine-tuned VGG16 Deep Learning Model
Affiliations: Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaur, Arshleen, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Sharma, Rishabh, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Chattopadhyay, Saumitra, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Joshi, Kireet, Computer Science & Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India
Abstract: Textile production plays a critical role in agriculture worldwide, and the cotton crop, which is the basis of this industry, suffers greatly from leaf diseases that are often very destructive and cause economic losses. This study presents a novel approach to the classification of four major cotton leaf diseases: Employing an exclusive VGG16 fine-tuned deep learning model to diagnose and evaluate cotton plant diseases such as Cotton Bacterial Blight, Verticillium Wilt, Fusarium Wilt, and Cotton Leaf Curl Disease. We employed a leaf image dataset to span a vast spectrum of signs symptoms conditions to pre-train and fine-tune the model. By performing diligent pre-training involving image augmentation and model adjustment for the particular task of cotton leaf disease detection, we found that VGG16 architecture is flexible enough to apply to our case. The model's performance was subject to a thorough assessment with the help of a different testing dataset proving the accuracy of a total classification of 93.8%. Precision score, recall score, and F1 score metrics also enlighten us that the model can accurately detect and classify the disease. The study reflects the possibility of creating the medium for fine-tuned deep-learning models in agricultural areas that represent an integral and efficient instrument for early disease detection and management. The results illuminated the actual consequences, and pathway for improvement of farm monitoring, minimized economic losses, and suggested support for sustainable farming practices. Future research will look into many dimensions: creating a bigger dataset, implementing other sophisticated architectures, and finally implementing real-world agricultural applications using the mentioned models. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Choudhury, Tanupriya (57193140084); Aich, Sumit (59204451100); Sar, Ayan (58881830900); Joshi, Purvika (59203684900); Pant, Bhaskar (35316278700); Dewangan, Bhupesh Kumar (57193869672)
Title: A Novel Framework for Tomato Disease Detection using YOLOv8
Affiliations: Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; University of Petroleum and Energy Studies, Dehradun, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; OP Jindal University, Raigarh, India
Authors with affiliations: Choudhury, Tanupriya, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India, School of Computer Science, University of Petroleum and Energy Studies, Dehradun, India; Aich, Sumit, School of Computer Science, University of Petroleum and Energy Studies, Dehradun, India; Sar, Ayan, School of Computer Science, University of Petroleum and Energy Studies, Dehradun, India; Joshi, Purvika, School of Computer Science, University of Petroleum and Energy Studies, Dehradun, India; Pant, Bhaskar, Department of CSE, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Dewangan, Bhupesh Kumar, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, OP Jindal University, Raigarh, India
Abstract: This unique method for recognising objects with YOLOv8 object detection will allow for the early identification of tomato diseases, which include blight, mould, and viral threats. And as this early identification is a key to global food security at this time, it is crucial. Automated technologies provide a solution to the cost and error-prone processes of classical diagnostics. Therefore, a tool based on them can improve diagnostic effectiveness. Based on YOLOv8's fruit defect detection technique and the use of Deep Learning, it yields fast and precise results in the recognition and classification of common diseases of tomatoes. The idea of training the model by curated dataset form and hyperparameter tuning will further optimise the model performance. For instance, precision, recall, and F1-score, known as the metrics, help me in determining the efficacy. Interpretation of the results reveals that these algorithms are more accurate and efficient than previous ones, prompting scientists and farmers to use the algorithm to take preventive measures in their operations, such as agriculture, horticulture, and crop management. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.A., Sri, M. Anusha; T., Srikanth, T.; S.R., Perumalla, Srinivasa Rao; N.S., Kumar, N. Satish; A., Athiraja, Atheeswaran; R., Nagalingam, Rajeswaran
Author full names: Sri, M. Anusha (59370716500); Srikanth, T. (58850091600); Perumalla, Srinivasa Rao (57215744175); Kumar, N. Satish (59901410600); Athiraja, Atheeswaran (57217825215); Nagalingam, Rajeswaran (55532403000)
Title: Revolutionizing Tomato Disease Detection: YOLOv5-Based Automated System for Agricultural Productivity and Food Security
Affiliations: Geethanjali College of Engineering and Technology, Medchal, India; Malla Reddy Engineering College for Women, Secunderabad, India; CVR College of Engineering, Ibrahimpatnam, India; Malla Reddy Engineering College, Secunderabad, Medchal, India; Malla Reddy Engineering College, Secunderabad, Medchal, India

Satish, Department of It, Malla Reddy Engineering College, Secunderabad, Medchal, India; Athiraja, Atheeswaran, Department of CSE, Malla Reddy Engineering College, Secunderabad, Medchal, India; Nagalingam, Rajeswaran, Department of CSE, Malla Reddy Engineering College, Secunderabad, Medchal, India
Abstract: Global food security and agricultural production are seriously threatened by tomato diseases. This research suggest a deep learning-based automated detection system, the YOLOv5 algorithm, which is well-known for its effectiveness in object identification tasks, to tackle this problem. Our approach uses a dataset with a variety of photos of both healthy and diseased tomato plants to train the YOLOv5 model to correctly detect and categorize different tomato crop illnesses. The trained model demonstrates exceptional performance in detecting common tomato diseases such as early blight, late blight, and bacterial spot, achieving high accuracy and robustness. Additionally, this work showcase the practical applicability of our approach by integrating the trained model into a user-friendly interface accessible via web or mobile applications. This enables farmers and agricultural stakeholders to promptly identify diseased plants in the field, facilitating timely interventions and mitigating crop losses. Our findings underscore the potential of deep learning algorithms such as YOLOv5 in revolutionizing disease management practices in agriculture, offering a promising avenue for enhancing crop yields and food security globally. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F., He, Feiyong; Y., Liu, Yue; J., Liu, Jinfeng
Title: ECA-ViT: Leveraging ECA and Vision Transformer for Crop Leaves Diseases Identification in Cultivation Environments
Affiliations: Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao; Guangdong Polytechnic of Science and Technology, Zhuhai, China
Authors with affiliations: He, Feiyong, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao; Liu, Yue, Faculty of Applied Sciences, Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao; Liu, Jinfeng, College of Robotics, Guangdong Polytechnic of Science and Technology, Zhuhai, China
Abstract: Crop disease identification is crucial for its role of maintaining crop yield and quality in precision agriculture. Traditional disease detection methods are often inefficient and error-prone. To address this issue, we propose the ECA-ViT model, which combines Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) and Vision Transformers (ViT) to identify crop leaf diseases in cultivation environments. The ECA-ViT model uses adaptive 1D convolution kernels for rapid cross-channel interaction of local disease features in crop images, compensating for the Vision Transformer's lack of global context understanding and optimizing the model. This balanced approach enhances feature learning while maintaining computational efficiency without increasing model complexity. We evaluated the ECA-ViT model using rice leaf disease datasets from real field settings. The results demonstrated that ECA-ViT outperformed existing deep lear-ning methods, achieving an accuracy of 95.41%. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: L.A., van Veen, Lara A.; H.D., Van den Brand, H. D.; A.C.M., van den Oever, Anna C.M.; B., Kemp, Bas; A.A., Youssef, A. A.
Author full names: van Veen, Lara A. (57222055703); Van den Brand, H. D. (9337142100); van den Oever, Anna C.M. (57211213445); Kemp, Bas (9332390800); Youssef, A. A. (53364879000)
Title: Towards an adaptive expert-in-the-loop algorithm for early detection of problems in laying hen flocks
Affiliations: Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands; Vencomatic Group, Eersel, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: van Veen, Lara A., Adaptation Physiology Group, Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands, Vencomatic Group, Eersel, Netherlands; Van den Brand, H. D., Adaptation Physiology Group, Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands; van den Oever, Anna C.M., Vencomatic Group, Eersel, Netherlands; Kemp, Bas, Adaptation Physiology Group, Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands; Youssef, A. A., Adaptation Physiology Group, Wageningen University & Research, Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: Laying hen farmers are expected to move towards an extended flock duration of 90 to 100 weeks as response to the increased global demand for food. Between-flock variability in the egg production curve is high, especially with layers in non-cage housing systems, due to environmental stressors, diseases and welfare issues. Lengthening the production period emphasizes the need to detect health and welfare issues early to prevent long-term effects on egg production and thereby retain profitable revenues. Current solutions for anomaly detection rely on comparing egg production data to inflexible, generic reference curves or on machine learning models with low confidence anomaly detection due to absence of expert feedback and model adaptability. The objective of this study is to develop an expert-in-the-loop algorithm for early problem detection and flock-specific prediction of egg production in layers. To identify anomalies in the egg production curve, the model compares daily acquired production data against an expert-defined adaptive reference trajectory. The model employs a one-class support vector machines that is continuously enhanced using feedback from the expert in case of low confidence anomalies. The proposed algorithm is trained using synthetic datasets and tested on real-world datasets. The results show that the proposed algorithm has high anomaly detection accuracy (96%) with an F1 score of 0.93. Ultimately, the proposed algorithm will facilitate predictive maintenance of egg production, thereby allowing for personalized support in decision-making. In the future, the algorithm could be adapted to detect anomalies in other age-dependent production parameters. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Mirhoseini Nejad, Seyed Mahdi, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shahid Bahonar University of Kerman, Kerman, Iran; Abbasi-Moghadam, Dariush, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shahid Bahonar University of Kerman, Kerman, Iran; Sharifi, Alireza, Water and Environmental Engineering, Shahid Beheshti University, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: This article introduces an approach for soybean yield prediction by integrating convolutional long short-term memory (ConvLSTM), three-dimensional convolutional neural network (3D-CNN), and vision transformer (ViT). By utilizing multispectral remote sensing data, our model leverages the spatial hierarchy of 3D-CNNs, the temporal sequencing capabilities of ConvLSTM, and the global context analysis of ViTs to capture complex patterns in agricultural datasets. The integration of these advanced methodologies allows for a comprehensive analysis of both spatial and temporal aspects of crop growth, enabling more accurate and robust predictions. Our experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model significantly outperforms existing methods, as evidenced by lower root mean square error and higher correlation coefficients. The 3D-CNN component effectively extracts spatial features from the multispectral images, while the ConvLSTM captures the temporal dynamics of crop development. The ViT further refines these features by focusing on the most relevant parts of the input data through self-attention mechanisms. The findings highlight the potential of this model in enhancing decision-making processes in crop management, particularly in precision agriculture. By providing more accurate yield predictions, the model can assist farmers in optimizing resource allocation, scheduling irrigation, and applying fertilizers more efficiently, thereby promoting sustainable farming practices. Furthermore, the model's robustness across various conditions underscores its applicability to different crops and geographic regions. This article contributes to the field of agricultural remote sensing by offering a robust solution to the complexities of analyzing large-scale, multispectral data. The proposed approach not only improves prediction accuracy but also provides timely and actionable insights for agricultural stakeholders. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: E.J.P., Bibangco, El Jireh P.; M.G.D., Dionson, Mary Gift D.; R.K.T., Javier, Reign Kenneth T.
Author full names: Bibangco, El Jireh P. (58038843400); Dionson, Mary Gift D. (59032217400); Javier, Reign Kenneth T. (59325431600)
Title: Convolutional Neural Network Architectures for Classification of Coffee Varieties in the Philippines
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Wireless Technology and Applications, ISWTA
Affiliations: Carlos Hilado Memorial State University, Talisay, Philippines; National University, Philippines, Manila, Philippines; Carlos Hilado Memorial State University, Talisay, Philippines
Authors with affiliations: Bibangco, El Jireh P., College of Computer Studies, Carlos Hilado Memorial State University, Talisay, Philippines; Dionson, Mary Gift D., College of Computing and Information Technologies, National University, Philippines, Manila, Philippines; Javier, Reign Kenneth T., Research and Development Office, Carlos Hilado Memorial State University, Talisay, Philippines
Abstract: This study investigates the application of advanced deep learning architectures in classifying coffee varieties, addressing the complexities and demands of the global coffee market. Given the limitations of traditional classification methods, which are labor-intensive and error-prone, this research explores the potential of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of coffee variety classification. Specifically, the study evaluated five CNN architectures—VGG19, ResNet152v2, DenseNet201, NASNetMobile, and NASNetLarge—on a self-captured dataset of 12,000 images representing four major coffee varieties available in the Philippine market: Arabica, Excelsa, Liberica, and Robusta. The research employs an experimental design to systematically assess each model's performance in handling complex image data. The models are rigorously tested across standardized metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, to determine their suitability for practical deployment in agricultural settings. Based on the results, DenseNet201 demonstrated the highest overall performance with precision, recall, and F1-score, all at 91% and an accuracy of 90%, suggesting its superior feature utilization and propagation capability. In contrast, other models like ResNet152V2 showed lower performance, indicating challenges in handling the dataset's variability. This study contributes to the technological advancements in agricultural practices and underscores the importance of integrating cutting-edge AI technologies to meet the specific needs of rapidly expanding markets like the Philippines. By providing a comparative analysis of CNN architectures, the research offers valuable insights into their application in precision agriculture, aiming to support sustainable development goals through improved crop management and quality assurance. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Bhatnagar, Shaleen; A., Chadalawada, Archit
Author full names: Bhatnagar, Shaleen (57194498220); Chadalawada, Archit (59325303400)
Title: Advancing Farming Practices: Machine Learning Algorithms for Optimal Crop Selection
Affiliations: Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Manipal, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhatnagar, Shaleen, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Manipal, India; Chadalawada, Archit, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Manipal, India
Abstract: This study underscores the critical importance of the agricultural sector for ensuring global food security and economic resilience, emphasizing the role of machine learning (ML)-enhanced crop recommendation systems. These systems are increasingly crucial for guiding farmers in choosing crops that are best suited to their unique soil and environmental conditions. Through the analysis of a comprehensive dataset, including soil composition, climate variations, historical crop yields, and agricultural practices, this research evaluates the performance of several ML algorithms-such as neural networks, decision trees, random forests, and support vector machines-in forecasting the most appropriate crops. Training on historical data allows these algorithms to decipher the complex dynamics between environmental factors and crop results. The success of these models is gauged by metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. This study also delves into the models' interpretability, offering crucial insights to both agricultural practitioners and researchers. Moreover, it presents the creation of a user-friendly web application that applies these ML models to provide personalized crop recommendations, requiring user inputs like geographical location, soil characteristics, and weather data. The findings reveal that ML algorithms can significantly empower farmers with knowledge to select suitable crops, thereby boosting agricultural efficiency, optimizing the use of resources, and enhancing the sustainability of agricultural operations. The research highlights the necessity of selecting the right ML algorithms and preprocessing techniques for achieving superior results. Notably, we have enhanced the accuracy of the random forest algorithm to 99.92% and ADABOOST with the Decision Tree Classifier to 99.02%. This contribution to precision agriculture showcases the practical use of ML in crop recommendation systems as a technological approach to addressing agricultural sector challenges and bolstering the global food supply chain. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: D., Banerjee, Deepak; N., Sharma, Neha; R., Chauhan, Rahul; M.K., Singh, Mukesh Kumar; B.V., Kumar, Bura Vijay
Author full names: Banerjee, Deepak (58244882000); Sharma, Neha (57199925014); Chauhan, Rahul (57220045108); Singh, Mukesh Kumar (58515758700); Kumar, Bura Vijay (57196374291)
Title: Innovative Solutions for Crop Health: A Hybrid Approach to Cotton Root Rot Severity Assessment
Affiliations: Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; SR University, Warangal, India
Authors with affiliations: Banerjee, Deepak, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Sharma, Neha, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Chauhan, Rahul, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Singh, Mukesh Kumar, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Kumar, Bura Vijay, School of Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence, SR University, Warangal, India
Abstract: The proposed study aims to enhance our comprehension and control of the gravity of cotton root rot by integrating agricultural practices with technological advancements. The combination of a CNN, which possesses knowledge, with an SVM greatly enhances its ability to detect root rot. It possesses great strength, exhibits high adaptability, and demonstrates exceptional speed in task execution. The test results indicate that Cotton, a significant component of global agriculture, is currently confronted with a persistent issue caused by detrimental root rot. The cause of this issue is Phymatotrichopsis omnivora, which has the potential to negatively impact productivity if not well managed. Effectively managing illnesses relies on meticulous and prompt attention to the severity of root rot. Executing this challenging undertaking requires innovative concepts to achieve success. This study used a mixed model as a response. The method combines the properties of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Support Vector Machine (SVM) to develop a sophisticated approach for quantifying the severity of cotton root rot infections. Our inquiry starts with a substantial collection of 9,000 dispersed photographs. These high-resolution photographs depict the several manifestations of root rot in plants in proximity. Demonstrating the effectiveness of our blend model, we present a comprehensive accuracy rate of 98.56%. This demonstrates its proficiency in providing accurate and comprehensive threat assessments. The model's accuracy, memory recall, and F1 score serve as indicators of its performance. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Vats, Tarun (58580153000); Mehra, Shrey (58546328100); Madan, Uday (57447356900); Chhabra, Amit (57539985500); Sharma, Akashdeep (55940987100); Chhabra, Kunal (58545619100); Singh, Sarabjeet N. (57189350466); Chauhan, Utkarsh (59236232400)
Title: NeuroRF FarmSense: IoT-fueled precision agriculture transformed for superior crop care
Source title: International Journal of Cognitive Computing in Engineering
Affiliations: Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Vellore Institute of Technology, Chennai, Chennai, India
Authors with affiliations: Vats, Tarun, UG Scholar, Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Mehra, Shrey, UG Scholar, Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Madan, Uday, UG Scholar, Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Chhabra, Amit, Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Sharma, Akashdeep, University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Chhabra, Kunal, UG Scholar, Vellore Institute of Technology, Chennai, Chennai, India; Singh, Sarabjeet N., Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India; Chauhan, Utkarsh, UG Scholar, Chandigarh College of Engineering and Technology, Chandigarh, India
Abstract: In light of the ongoing global hunger crisis, it is imperative to improve food production in accordance with Sustainable Development Goal 2.0, which aims to eliminate hunger while promoting sustainable agricultural practices. This research presents a novel Internet of Things (IoT)-driven crop management system, NeuroRF FarmSense, specifically designed for precision agriculture. By utilizing soil sensors and a robust IoT framework, this system enables effective data collection across vast and remote agricultural areas. The study utilizes an extensive Crop Recommendation Dataset obtained from Kaggle, which includes 2,200 entries and seven critical attributes essential for crop selection: phosphorus, humidity, potassium, temperature, nitrogen, pH, and rainfall. This dataset provides a detailed methodology for crop recommendations, revealing more than 22 alternative crops based on varying characteristics. For agricultural forecasting, the NeuroRF FarmSense system employs the NeuroRF Classifier, which integrates neural networks (NN) with the Random Forest Classifier, achieving an unprecedented accuracy of 99.82%, exceeding prior records. This integrative approach harnesses the advantages of NN's ReLU activation and dropout regularization alongside the robustness of RF. By utilizing NN predictions as input features for RF training and refining RF through grid search with cross-validation, the ensemble model produces highly precise predictions, facilitating strategic crop cultivation for optimal yields across diverse environmental conditions. This innovative methodology signifies a strong solution for classification challenges in precision agriculture. By merging IoT technology with machine learning algorithms, smart farming is poised to enter a transformative phase, providing a scalable response to the pressing issues of global food security. This research aspires to advance precision agriculture in harmony with global sustainability objectives. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: A Deep Learning Approach to Potato Late Blight Detection: Developing and Evaluating a Lightweight Single-Stage Detection Model
Source title: Lecture Notes in Networks and Systems
Affiliations: Université Mohammed Premier Oujda, Oujda, Morocco; Faculté des Sciences d’Oujda, Oujda, Morocco; Université Mohammed Premier Oujda, Oujda, Morocco
Authors with affiliations: Zarrouk, Yassine, Université Mohammed Premier Oujda, Oujda, Morocco; Bourhaleb, Mohammed, Université Mohammed Premier Oujda, Oujda, Morocco; Rahmoune, Mohammed, Université Mohammed Premier Oujda, Oujda, Morocco; Hachami, Khalid, Université Mohammed Premier Oujda, Oujda, Morocco; Hamdaoui, Hajar, Faculté des Sciences d’Oujda, Oujda, Morocco; Al Kaddouri, Hanae, SmartICT Lab, Université Mohammed Premier Oujda, Oujda, Morocco
Abstract: Detecting and identifying crop diseases in their early stages remains a challenge in modern agricultural practices, affecting yield and food security worldwide. Potato late blight, caused by Phytophthora infestans is a serious threat to potato crops requiring fast and accurate detection methods to minimize losses. A new approach using deep learning was suggested in this study to spot this disease at an early stage. The study focused on developing and training a YOLOv8n model with a dataset of 14,150 images and annotations from Berkane, Morocco. This dataset was carefully chosen to cover a diverse range of symptoms and stages of potato blight under different environmental conditions to ensure the model’s reliability, robustness, and generalizability. The model is known for its suitable design for real-time decisions in agricultural settings due to its lightweight size. However, this experiment shows that YOLOv8n has a modest detection performance on complex and diverse datasets, making it an interesting opportunity for enhancing research towards early intervention against potato late blight using lightweight models - the potential of deep learning to improve farming methods. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Y., Peng, Yihang; H., Jiang, Honghui; F., Wang, Fu
Title: A PVT based wheat detection method
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Anhui Technical College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Wuhu, China
Authors with affiliations: Peng, Yihang, Anhui Technical College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Wuhu, China; Jiang, Honghui, Anhui Technical College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Wuhu, China; Wang, Fu, Anhui Technical College of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Wuhu, China
Abstract: Wheat detection is significant in agriculture and can help farmers achieve efficient planting management and precision agriculture. Traditional wheat detection methods usually rely on hand-designed feature extractors and classifiers, but the ability and generalization of feature representations limit their performance. In contrast, deep learning-based methods can automatically learn feature representations and perform end-to-end training on large-scale datasets, with more vital representation ability and generalization. In this study, we propose a PVT-based detection method for wheat. PVT is a visual model combining a Transformer and feature pyramid, simultaneously capturing global and local information in images. The experimental results show that the PVT model is adaptable and can be generalized in wheat detection. It can provide accurate detection results of wheat ears and maintain stability when dealing with different light conditions and wheat growth cycles. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Harish, M.; T., Vijaya Kumar, T.; P., Rajasekaran, P.; P., Poovizhi, P.; G., Pondinesh, G.; R.R., Vigneshwaran, R. Ragavendra
Author full names: Harish, M. (59507499500); Vijaya Kumar, T. (57957864600); Rajasekaran, P. (57656094400); Poovizhi, P. (36633036800); Pondinesh, G. (59313625100); Vigneshwaran, R. Ragavendra (58806715500)
Title: Analysis on Early Prediction of Cotton Plant Leaf Diseases Using CatBoost Algorithm
Affiliations: Dr. NG. P. Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India

Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Pondinesh, G., Department of Information Technology, Dr. NG. P. Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Vigneshwaran, R. Ragavendra, Department of Information Technology, Dr. NG. P. Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India
Abstract: As the global population steadily increases, the imperative for improved crop production becomes increasingly critical to ensure food security for everyone. Addressing agricultural diseases is a primary step, requiring the identification and widespread monitoring of these ailments. To solve this problem, the proposed project introduces a robust Cotton Leaf Diseases Detection System employing advanced machine learning techniques. Leveraging the VGG16 model, the system extracts essential features from cotton leaf images and stores them in a CSV file. The Cat Boost algorithm is then applied to the datasets for training, resulting in the creation of a highly accurate model file. This model showcases excellent classification capabilities, allowing for the detection of various cotton leaves diseases. The project optimizes the accuracy and efficiency of disease detection by integrating deep learning and gradient boosting. The integration of image feature extraction and Cat Boost algorithm not only enhances the system's performance but also offers a scalable and adaptable solution for real-world applications. This pioneering approach represents a notable progression in precision agriculture, contributing significantly to the early and accurate diagnosis of cotton leaf diseases. This, in turn, contributes to more effective crop management strategies. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Leaf Analysis for Disease Identification using Transfer learning
Affiliations: Delhi Technological University, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Beniwal, Rohit S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Delhi Technological University, New Delhi, India; Sachin, Sachin, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Delhi Technological University, New Delhi, India; Satyam, Satyam, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Delhi Technological University, New Delhi, India; Kumar, Saroj, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Delhi Technological University, New Delhi, India
Abstract: The escalating challenges in agricultural efficiency due to plant diseases require advanced solutions for early detection and administration. Conventional strategies, despite being viable to a degree, need the exactness, speed, and adaptability required to relieve these challenges effectively. This research presents a novel approach to plant disease identification leveraging the control of transfer learning. By focusing on basic crops such as wheat, rice, corn, and sugarcane, this study points to revolutionizing leaf investigation for disease location, advertising a critical jump toward precision agriculture. Utilizing a comprehensive dataset comprising pictures of solid and unhealthy clears out, we prepared and assessed models for each trim, accomplishing exceptional exactnesses: 98.33% for corn and 97.37% for wheat, and over 90% for rice and sugarcane. These come about to emphasize the adequacy of transfer learning in improving the model capacity to generalize over different plant infections, in this manner empowering more precise and dependable malady discovery. The suggestions of our discoveries amplify past scholastic intrigue, advertising down-to-earth arrangements for agriculturists and rural experts around the world, subsequently supporting economical rural homes in the confrontation of worldwide nourishment security challenges. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: B., Chen, Baoyu; S., Li, Shuting; J., He, Jingmei; F., He, Feiyong; Y., Hu, Yingbiao; J., Chen, Jingjia; L., Huinian, Li
Title: USST: Utilizing SimAM and SGA Techniques to Cassava Leaf Diseases Classification in Real Cultivation Environments
Affiliations: Dongguan University of Technology, Dongguan, China; Macau University of Science and Technology, Taipa, Macao; Guangdong University of Finance, Guangzhou, China; Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao; Guangzhou University, Guangzhou, China; Guangdong Polytechnic of Science and Trade, Guangzhou, China

Abstract: Cassava leaf diseases devastate crop yield and quality, posing a significant threat to food security in Africa. Limited by accuracy and processing speed, traditional detection methods hinder effective disease management. We introduce USST, a novel cassava leaf disease detection approach to address this challenge. USST employs a synergistic combination of two attention mechanisms for enhanced feature learning: optimized self-guided attention (SGA) captures global disease patterns. In contrast, a simple and efficient attention mechanism (simAM) precisely identifies disease-related regions in cassava leaf images. Our extensive experiments demonstrate that USST's comprehensive integration of global and local perspectives is highly effective for cassava leaf disease identification, especially in real plant environments. This approach surpasses previous methods in both accuracy and efficiency. On the Cassava Leaf Diseases Dataset, USST achieved an industry-leading accuracy of 88.48%, significantly outperforming established methodologies. This automated disease identification method presents an effective solution for farmers, with the potential to revolutionize agricultural practices. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T.A., Mir, Taifa Ayoub; D., Banerjee, Deepak; P., Aggarwal, Priyanshi; R.S., Rawat, Ramesh Singh; G.L., Sunil, Goli L.
Author full names: Mir, Taifa Ayoub (59134384400); Banerjee, Deepak (58244882000); Aggarwal, Priyanshi (58174959700); Rawat, Ramesh Singh (57215855215); Sunil, Goli L. (57209137355)
Title: Improved Potato Disease Classification: Synergy of CNN and SVM Models
Affiliations: Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India
Authors with affiliations: Mir, Taifa Ayoub, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Banerjee, Deepak, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Aggarwal, Priyanshi, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Rawat, Ramesh Singh, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Sunil, Goli L., Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Abstract: Establishing a model to reliably diagnose potato leaf diseases is a challenging but crucial agricultural technology. The study proposes a robust classification model using CNN and SVM. The table displays the model's high F1-Score, accuracy, and recall across several illness classes. Recall and accuracy scores between 92.86% and 95.17% indicate how effectively the model finds acceptable instances and makes excellent predictions. F1-score, which ranges from 92.99% to 94.85%, indicates the model can distinguish circumstances. It works for 655 to 725 instances of each illness class, according to support figures. Our classifier can discover numerous potato illnesses with 98% accuracy. The wide, weighted, and micro means, which range from 94.24% to 94.26% across categories, further aid the model. The model's sickness detection accuracy and agricultural potential are shown using modern machine learning approaches. This precise model can distinguish healthy leaves from rust, Powdery Scab, Leaf Roll Virus, Late Blight, and Early Dying Syndrome. The model is reliable and constant among parameters, making it useful for potato disease detection. This breakthrough improves precision agriculture by helping farmers identify ill potato crops early. It reduces production costs and promotes environmentally friendly farming. For each illness class, 655-725 instances demonstrate the model's cross-dataset performance. With 98% accuracy, the classification model can identify potato illnesses. Global, weighted, and micro means, which vary from 94.24% to 94.26% depending on the measure, improve the model. Combining contemporary machine learning algorithms illustrates how precise the model can be for identifying diseases and farming. Model performance distinguishes rust, late blight, early blight, leaf roll virus, powdery scab, and early dying syndrome. The model consistently satisfies several variables, making it an excellent potato disease detection tool. This discovery helps us detect potato crop illnesses early and accurately, advancing precision agriculture. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Li, Shuting; B., Chen, Baoyu; F., Li, Feng; J., He, Jingmei; F., He, Feiyong; Y., Hu, Yingbiao; J., Chen, Jingjia; L., Huinian, Li
Title: PlantViQ: Disease Recognition Across Varied Environments with Vision Transformer and Quadrangle Attention
Affiliations: Macau University of Science and Technology, Taipa, Macao; Dongguan University of Technology, Dongguan, China; Guangdong Innovative Technical College, Dongguan, China; Guangdong University of Finance, Guangzhou, China; Macao Polytechnic University, Macau, Macao; Guangzhou University, Guangzhou, China; Guangdong Polytechnic of Science and Trade, Guangzhou, China

Abstract: Accurate plant disease detection in real-world agricultural settings poses a significant challenge due to the complex and variable nature of field environments. To address this challenge, we introduce PlantViQ. This deep learning model leverages the strengths of both convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for local feature extraction and Transformers for capturing global context. This enables PlantViQ to overcome the limitations of traditional CNN-based approaches, particularly in scenarios with small-sample datasets and challenging environmental conditions. As demonstrated by its exceptional F1-score of 88.52% on cassava leaf disease and 97.21% on rice leaf disease, PlantViQ has the potential to revolutionize crop management practices by enabling early and accurate disease detection even in the most challenging real-world environments. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Patil, Priyadarshini M. (57216116957); Pamali, Sneha K. (58674452000); Devagiri, Shreya B. (58674451900); Sushma, A. S. (59218958500); Mirje, Jyothi (59218958600)
Title: Plant Leaf disease detection using XAI
Affiliations: KLE Technological University, Hubli, India
Authors with affiliations: Patil, Priyadarshini M., KLE Technological University, Hubli, India; Pamali, Sneha K., KLE Technological University, Hubli, India; Devagiri, Shreya B., KLE Technological University, Hubli, India; Sushma, A. S., KLE Technological University, Hubli, India; Mirje, Jyothi, KLE Technological University, Hubli, India
Abstract: In the realm of agriculture, where crop health is integral to global food security, Our focus is on the early detection of crop diseases. Leveraging Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) on a diverse dataset of crop images, our study focuses on the development, training, and optimization of these networks to achieve accurate and timely disease classification. The first segment demonstrates the efficacy of CNN architecture and optimization strategy, showcasing the potential of deep learning models in automating the identification process. The synergy of robust disease detection and interpretability through Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) presented in this work marks a significant stride toward bridging the gap between advanced technology and precision agriculture. By employing visualization, the research seeks to unravel the decision-making processes of our models. XAI Visualization method emerges as notably superior in terms of accuracy, hinting at its better identification of the disease, this method achieves an accuracy of 89.75%, surpassing both the heat map model and the LIME explanation method. This not only enhances the transparency and trustworthiness of the predictions but also provides invaluable insights for end-users, allowing them to comprehend the diagnostic features considered by the complex algorithm. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: F., Ahmed, Faruk; Y.R., Emon, Yousuf Rayhan; M.T., Ahad, Md Taimur; M.H., Munna, Mehedi Hasan; S.B., Mamun, Sajib Bin
Author full names: Ahmed, Faruk (58722450500); Emon, Yousuf Rayhan (58598925300); Ahad, Md Taimur (56580036100); Munna, Mehedi Hasan (58601151700); Mamun, Sajib Bin (59217629200)
Title: A Fuzzy-Based Vision Transformer Model for Tea Leaf Disease Detection
Source title: Lecture Notes in Networks and Systems
Affiliations: Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Ahmed, Faruk, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Emon, Yousuf Rayhan, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Ahad, Md Taimur, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Munna, Mehedi Hasan, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Mamun, Sajib Bin, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Abstract: Recently, vision transformer has gained significant attention in the field of precision agriculture for its ability to transfer knowledge from pre-trained deep models. However, very small studies shed light on the capabilities of ViT on tea leaf disease detection. Early diagnosis and detection of tea leaf diseases are crucial for ensuring tea plant health and preventing yield and quality reductions in the tea industry. The existing research in tea leaf disease detection could not achieve better accuracy using different models in publicly available datasets. This study fills this gap by implementing vision transformer (ViT) to diagnose tea leaf diseases. Our primary dataset, drawn from two prominent Bangladeshi tea estates, includes five diseased classes and one healthy class. After in-depth training, our model showcased an exceptional testing accuracy rate of 99.53% in 292 s using (Image [56  ×  56], patch 7). As all countries aim to enhance their position in the global tea market for a sustainable economy, tea plant production is important. Our research can be a foundational tool for increasing the quantity of tea production by early detection of tea leaf diseases. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.B., Mamun, Sajib Bin; M.T., Ahad, Md Taimur; M.M., Morshed, Md Monzur; N., Hossain, Nafiull; Y.R., Emon, Yousuf Rayhan
Author full names: Mamun, Sajib Bin (59217629200); Ahad, Md Taimur (56580036100); Morshed, Md Monzur (59217205700); Hossain, Nafiull (59216912900); Emon, Yousuf Rayhan (58598925300)
Title: Scratch Vision Transformer Model for Diagnosis Grape Leaf Disease
Source title: Lecture Notes in Networks and Systems
Affiliations: Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Mamun, Sajib Bin, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Ahad, Md Taimur, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Morshed, Md Monzur, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Hossain, Nafiull, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Emon, Yousuf Rayhan, Daffodil International University, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Abstract: Recently, vision transformer has gained significant attention in the field of precision agriculture for its ability to transfer knowledge from pre-trained deep models for downstream tasks, particularly with limited datasets. However, very small studies shed light on the capabilities of grape disease detection. Grape is an important fruit worldwide, and early diagnosis and detection of grape diseases are crucial for ensuring plant health and preventing yield and quality reductions in the grape-growing industry. To fill the gap, this study developed a vision transformer model for the diagnosis of grape leaf disease. To provide a comprehensive understanding of ViT, in this study, the experiments were conducted with different image sizes and patch sizes of grape leaf images. Moreover, to extend the capabilities, both augmented and non-augmented datasets were used in the experiment configurations on two types of datasets, and the proposed model can provide quite similar output for both data (augmented and without augmented) in classifying grape disease, with approximately 98–99% validation and testing accuracy. This achievement highlights the potential of integrating advanced deep learning tools into the nation’s agricultural practices. As worldwide fruit demands are increasing, this study provides a foundation for how machine learning techniques can be implemented to increase fruit production by identifying diseases. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
