Authors: D., Kinaneva, Diyana; G.V., Hristov, Georgi Valentinov; G.D., Georgiev, Georgi Dimitrov; P.Z., Zahariev, Plamen Z.
Author full names: Kinaneva, Diyana (56891737600); Hristov, Georgi Valentinov (24472522600); Georgiev, Georgi Dimitrov (57203103880); Zahariev, Plamen Z. (24829549600)
Title: Machine Learning Algorithms for Data Mining and Predictive Analytics in Precision Agriculture
Affiliations: University of Rousse, Ruse, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Kinaneva, Diyana, Department of Telecommunications, University of Rousse, Ruse, Bulgaria; Hristov, Georgi Valentinov, Department of Telecommunications, University of Rousse, Ruse, Bulgaria; Georgiev, Georgi Dimitrov, Department of Telecommunications, University of Rousse, Ruse, Bulgaria; Zahariev, Plamen Z., Department of Telecommunications, University of Rousse, Ruse, Bulgaria
Abstract: Artificial intelligence is a global topic that holds significant importance in recent years. It sparks debates about its usage, but despite the contradictions that arise, there are many benefits to applying it in various areas. In this paper, the authors investigate the possibilities of implementing machine learning algorithms to help optimize crop management for precision agriculture. Meeting current food demands becomes an increasingly challenging task as the population grows. Applying machine learning using IoT data analytics in the agricultural sector will bring forth additional advantages, increasing not only the quantity but also the quality of production from crop fields to meet the rising food demands. The main objective of the paper is to employ various machine learning algorithms for predictive modeling and subsequently develop a robust model capable of making accurate predictions on unseen agricultural data. The research methodology involves preprocessing the acquired dataset, including data cleaning and feature engineering to enhance model performance. The authors systematically apply a range of machine learning algorithms, such as Logistic regression, Decision trees, Naïve Bayes, and k-nearest Neighbor, to identify the most effective approach for crop yield prediction. For better model performance, boosting techniques of machine learning are also implemented. Cross-validation and performance metrics such as accuracy, confusion matrix, precision, recall and F1 score, are included to evaluate the accuracy of the models, aiming to highlight the strengths and weaknesses of each algorithm in the context of precision agriculture. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A.A., Stone, Abigail A.; S., Rajeev, Srijith; S.P., Rao, Shishir Paramathma; K.A., Panetta, Karen A.; S.S., Agaian, Sos S.
Author full names: Stone, Abigail A. (57845246100); Rajeev, Srijith (58522672400); Rao, Shishir Paramathma (57191541404); Panetta, Karen A. (6507727793); Agaian, Sos S. (35321805400)
Title: Towards phenological development quantification in Brassica plants via multispectral imaging and deep learning
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Tufts School of Engineering, Medford, United States; The Grove School of Engineering, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stone, Abigail A., Tufts School of Engineering, Medford, United States; Rajeev, Srijith, Tufts School of Engineering, Medford, United States; Rao, Shishir Paramathma, Tufts School of Engineering, Medford, United States; Panetta, Karen A., Tufts School of Engineering, Medford, United States; Agaian, Sos S., The Grove School of Engineering, New York, United States
Abstract: As global populations soar and the climate warms, food supply management is an increasingly critical problem. Precision agriculture, driven by on-site data collected from various sensors, plays a pivotal role in optimizing irrigation, fertilization, and enhancing plant health and crop yield. However, the manual process of in-filed chlorophyll measurement, which is a key metric for guiding agricultural decisions, is very cumbersome and poses significant challenges. This paper explores the transformative potential of multispectral imaging data to automate plant measuring and monitoring tasks, thereby reducing labor and time costs while improving the quality of data available for making informed agricultural decisions. We present a deep-learning model for instance segmentation of plants, trained on the Growliflower dataset of RGB and multispectral image cubes of cauliflower plants. The proposed algorithm uses a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to leverage both the spectral information and and its spatial context to locate individual plants. We introduce a novel band-selection algorithm for determining the most significant multispectral features for use in the convolutional network: this reduces model complexity while ensuring accurate results. Our model’s ability to generalize across varying growth stages, soil conditions, and varieties of crops in the training dataset demonstrates its suitability for real-world agricultural applications. This fusion of cutting-edge sensing technology for robotic systems and state-of-the-art deep learning models holds significant promise for advancements in crop yield, resource efficiency, and sustainability practices. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Dua, Aashvi; A., Sharda, Ajay; W.T., Schapaugh, William T.; R., Hessel, Rene
Author full names: Dua, Aashvi (59204034200); Sharda, Ajay (35196920800); Schapaugh, William T. (6602563189); Hessel, Rene (59204034300)
Title: Automated pipeline for multi-polygon shapefile generation for phenotype and precision agriculture applications
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Carl R. Ice College of Engineering, Manhattan, United States; Kansas State University, Manhattan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dua, Aashvi, Carl R. Ice College of Engineering, Manhattan, United States; Sharda, Ajay, Carl R. Ice College of Engineering, Manhattan, United States; Schapaugh, William T., Kansas State University, Manhattan, United States; Hessel, Rene, Kansas State University, Manhattan, United States
Abstract: The plant breeding community has increasingly adopted remote sensing platforms like unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to collect crop phenotype data. These platforms captured high-resolution multi-spectral (MS) image data during extensive field trials, enabling concurrent evaluation of thousands of plots with diverse seed varieties and management practices. However, breeders still relied on manual and intricate data extraction, processing, and analysis of high-resolution imagery for drawing results. A significant challenge was identifying plot locations within MS imagery, delineating plot boundaries, and providing spatial references to each plot. Therefore, the study was conducted to develop an automated methodology for creating multiple polygon shape files with unique identifiers for overlaying drone imagery data with centimeter-level accuracy for obtaining zonal statistics of each phenotype plot. The goal was to develop a pipeline without assuming field uniformity, plot spacing, size, or quantity, minimizing the need for manual adjustments. The proposed method used a high-accuracy planter-logged Real-Time Kinematic Global Positioning System (RTK-GPS) and georeferenced MS-UAV imagery. This process automatically generated plot boundaries by converting RTK-GPS points to polygons representing each planted plot. The resulting pipeline automatically produced maps of Vegetative Indices (VI), multi-polygon shape files, and CSV files of plot boundaries for external software and downstream analysis. Notably, the polygon shape file consistently aligned with plot boundaries within the image and even across temporal data sets with the least manual adjustments. This approach provided an efficient, adaptable, and replicable automated solution, minimizing time, labor, and user involvement while facilitating zonal statistics extraction of each phenotype plot from MS imagery. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Tasfe, Mahrin; A., Nivrito, Akm; F., Al-Machot, Fadi; M., Ullah, Mohib; H., Ullah, Habib
Author full names: Tasfe, Mahrin (57202137446); Nivrito, Akm (59193938600); Al-Machot, Fadi (37010953300); Ullah, Mohib (7006278145); Ullah, Habib (59086654000)
Title: Deep Learning Based Models for Paddy Disease Identification and Classification: A Systematic Survey
Affiliations: Norges Miljø- og Biovitenskapelige Universitet, As, Norway; Independent Researcher, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Norges Teknisk-Naturvitenskapelige Universitet, Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Tasfe, Mahrin, Norges Miljø- og Biovitenskapelige Universitet, As, Norway; Nivrito, Akm, Independent Researcher, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Al-Machot, Fadi, Norges Miljø- og Biovitenskapelige Universitet, As, Norway; Ullah, Mohib, Norges Teknisk-Naturvitenskapelige Universitet, Trondheim, Norway; Ullah, Habib, Norges Miljø- og Biovitenskapelige Universitet, As, Norway
Abstract: Automated early detection and classification of paddy diseases help in applying treatment efficiently according to the detected diseases. Early detection also minimises the usage of chemical substances and pesticides and hinders the spread of the disease to healthy crops. On a broader scale, it aids in halting the global spread of diseases. Thus, it ultimately promotes healthier rice crops and increased yield. In this survey paper, we present a thorough exploration of deep learning (DL) models for the classification of paddy diseases. Our paper delves into the motivation behind this research study, reveals different paddy diseases and their associated symptoms, and unravels various deep-learning models employed for disease detection. We have also discussed strategies used by researchers for improving the performance of DL models, along with adaptations tailored for application-specific contexts. Additionally, we illustrate relevant research findings, explore datasets utilised in this domain, and analyse approaches for data augmentation. Through an exhaustive investigation, we emphasise existing research gaps, challenges, and open issues, concluding in a discussion on avenues for future exploration. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Selva Kumar, S.; A.K.M.A., Khan, Afifah Khan Mohammed Ajmal; I.A., Banday, Imadh Ajaz; M., Gada, Manikantha; V.V., Shanbhag, Vibha Venkatesh
Author full names: Selva Kumar, S. (57194090806); Khan, Afifah Khan Mohammed Ajmal (58752795500); Banday, Imadh Ajaz (58751858600); Gada, Manikantha (59154339600); Shanbhag, Vibha Venkatesh (59155004500)
Title: Overcoming LLM Challenges using RAG-Driven Precision in Coffee Leaf Disease Remediation
Affiliations: B.M.S. College of Engineering, Bengaluru, India
Authors with affiliations: Selva Kumar, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, B.M.S. College of Engineering, Bengaluru, India; Khan, Afifah Khan Mohammed Ajmal, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, B.M.S. College of Engineering, Bengaluru, India; Banday, Imadh Ajaz, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, B.M.S. College of Engineering, Bengaluru, India; Gada, Manikantha, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, B.M.S. College of Engineering, Bengaluru, India; Shanbhag, Vibha Venkatesh, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, B.M.S. College of Engineering, Bengaluru, India
Abstract: This research introduces an innovative AI-driven precision agriculture system, leveraging YOLOv8 for disease identification and Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) for context-aware diagnosis. Focused on addressing the challenges of diseases affecting the coffee production sector in Karnataka, The system integrates sophisticated object detection techniques with language models to address the inherent constraints associated with Large Language Models (LLMs). Our methodology not only tackles the issue of hallucinations in LLMs, but also introduces dynamic disease identification and remediation strategies. Real-time monitoring, collaborative dataset expansion, and organizational involvement ensure the system's adaptability in diverse agricultural settings. The effect of the suggested system extends beyond automation, aiming to secure food supplies, protect livelihoods, and promote eco-friendly farming practices. By facilitating precise disease identification, the system contributes to sustainable and environmentally conscious agriculture, reducing reliance on pesticides. Looking to the future, the project envisions continuous development in RAG-integrated object detection systems, emphasizing scalability, reliability, and usability. This research strives to be a beacon for positive change in agriculture, aligning with global efforts toward sustainable and technologically enhanced food production. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M., Bakshi, Manan; P., Chugh, Priyal; V., Arulalan, V.
Author full names: Bakshi, Manan (58259136300); Chugh, Priyal (59171889800); Arulalan, V. (56809436800)
Title: Rice Leaf Disease Detection for Precision Agriculture
Affiliations: SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India
Authors with affiliations: Bakshi, Manan, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; Chugh, Priyal, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; Arulalan, V., SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India
Abstract: Rice being crucial for sustaining over half of the global population, is recognized as one of the foremost plants in agriculture worldwide. The presence of diseases affecting rice plants can significantly influence both the quantity and quality of the harvest, sometimes resulting in crop losses ranging from 30 to 60%. This work focuses on automating the recognition and categorization of common rice leaf diseases using deep learning, particularly with respect to the DenseNet architecture. Preprocessing methods, the deployment of DenseNet for disease diagnosis, and the gathering of an extensive dataset are all part of this work. The efficacy of the model is demonstrated by the high recall, accuracy, and precision rates of the experimental data. This work presents the effectiveness of DenseNet, explores the implications of the results for precision agriculture, and identifies future directions for deep learning-based plant disease detection research © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J., Joshi, Jyoti; M., Aeri, Manisha; V., Kukreja, Vinay; S., Mehta, Shiva
Author full names: Joshi, Jyoti (57221981949); Aeri, Manisha (57216865924); Kukreja, Vinay (49661773100); Mehta, Shiva (58847208600)
Title: Revolutionizing in Agriculture: Federated CNN Models for Sunflower Leaf Diseases
Affiliations: Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Authors with affiliations: Joshi, Jyoti, Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Aeri, Manisha, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Kukreja, Vinay, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Mehta, Shiva, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Abstract: With the advent of an age when the reason for adopting precision agriculture to ensure essential food security and economic sustainability is foremost, the precise recognition and tattooing of sunflower leaf disease is an inauspicious part of agricultural study. In a learning process characterized by interconnectedness, collaboration, and data protection and confidentiality maintenance, the five participants (xc_1 to xc_5) have applied different data representations to the model. The summary explains our approach to analytical matters, citing the influence of global and local data analyzed via the trained AI model using federated averaging. The most considerable average accuracy was observed for all clients at xc_5, 95.71%, whereas the first version was much lower at xc_1, only 88.76%. It demonstrated clear progress from the eventual to the initial stages of the model learning without bias towards certain classes. Weighted averages are essential to the analysis of the datasets where there are imbalances. With xc_1, the weighted average starts at 89.15 and reaches the top with xc_5 of 95.72. The fact that it is more accurate and adaptable when categorizing common diseases is demonstrated by the improved precision that is illustrated in general. The micro average is the resultant average that depicts the general model accuracy, while the weight averages are the averages based on the weight. To be specific, the accuracy for sample 1 reached 89.13%, and sample 5 overviewed the accuracy level and reached 95.72%. The core of the work is federated averaging, which transforms the world's local neighborhood analytics into a universal understanding of the world. It refers to the mix of local training for separate models inside and outside the globe. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Chattopadhyay, Saumitra; A., Verma, Aditya; A., Srivastava, Ankur; V., Kukreja, Vinay; S., Mehta, Shiva; H., Shanmugasundaram, Hariharan
Author full names: Chattopadhyay, Saumitra (57268881400); Verma, Aditya (57223041283); Srivastava, Ankur (59134361000); Kukreja, Vinay (49661773100); Mehta, Shiva (58847208600); Shanmugasundaram, Hariharan (57955605100)
Title: Cauliflower Leaf Disease: Unraveling Severity Levels with Federated Learning CNN
Affiliations: Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; IIMT College of Engineering, Greater Noida, Greater Noida, India; Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Chattopadhyay, Saumitra, Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Verma, Aditya, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Srivastava, Ankur, Computer Science and Engineering (Artificial Intelligence), IIMT College of Engineering, Greater Noida, Greater Noida, India; Kukreja, Vinay, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Mehta, Shiva, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Shanmugasundaram, Hariharan, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: The present research deals with a new approach to precision agriculture, particularly the classification of cauliflower leaf disease using Federated Learning (FL) integrated into Convolutional Neural Networks. The study presents a new categorization scheme for leaf diseases that uses four severity levels based on the distribution of a dataset through 4 different clients. It aimed to exploit the decentralized nature of FL to improve data privacy while benefiting from powerful image classification potentials offered by CNNs. Two of the four clients in our study, fq1 to fq4, provided local data combined via Federated Averaging into a global model. The result analysis applied three key metrics: macro, micro, and weighted averages that portray the model's local and international performance. The results from every client indicated a steady increase in classification accuracy. The Macro Average at approximately even treatment of all the classes increased steadily from fq-1 (96.35%) until fq-4 (99.11%). Similarly, the Weighted Average that considers class representation began at 96.45% for f q-1 and ended at 99.10 % table for fq-4. The same pattern was obtained with the Micro Average in which contributions from all classes are summed up to have this average increased markedly, that is, 96.44% for fq-1 and sharply rises to a total of 99.10%% it reached its peak at time f: When computing based on percentages correctly assigned, the assumption made right before Class These averages show the overall balanced performance of the model for different severity classes regardless whether they appear more often in a dataset or not. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Maldonado, Sebastian; G., Escuder, Gonzalo; A., Seré, Andrés; L., Steinfeld, Leonardo
Author full names: Maldonado, Sebastian (59043590600); Escuder, Gonzalo (59044723700); Seré, Andrés (57209469685); Steinfeld, Leonardo (36572380300)
Title: Open-Source Cellular IoT Technologies Coverage Data Collection System for Precision Agriculture
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Administracion Nacional de, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Maldonado, Sebastian, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Escuder, Gonzalo, Administracion Nacional de, Montevideo, Uruguay; Seré, Andrés, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Steinfeld, Leonardo, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In remote rural areas, cellular IoT coverage remains limited and exhibits geographical variations, often leading to unreliable connectivity or even complete lack thereof. Mobile operators cannot afford comprehensive coverage assessments conducted through drive testing to provide coverage maps, hindering a wider adoption of IoT solutions for precision agriculture. However, system integrators and farmers could conduct on-demand field coverage assessments to evaluate the feasibility of embracing cellular as a Low Power Wide Area Network (LPWAN) communication technology in their production units if an affordable tool were accessible. This work proposes an open-source tool for cellular IoT coverage analysis. The system comprises a low-cost, portable, and autonomous device with a Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) chip and a cellular modem. Constructed using affordable, interconnectable kits (Arduino Zero and a Quectel BG96 modem board) powered by a power bank, it offers several hours of energy autonomy. The device collects network information and transmits it in georeferenced form via MQTT (Message Queuing Telemetry Transport) to a server for storage and user-friendly visualization. The server side is composed of four open-source systems. Eclipse Mosquitto serves as the system's core, implementing the MQTT protocol. Telegraf, a server-based agent, subscribes to Mosquitto topics, extracts data from JSON-formatted messages, and sends it to InfluxDB, a time-series database, for storage. Finally, Grafana serves as a powerful web-based data visualization system, retrieving and displaying InfluxDB data through a color-coded map. Experimental results demonstrate the exceptional potential and effectiveness of the proposed solution. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: T., Jothimalar, T.; S., Daniel Madan Raja, S.; C., Bennila Thangammal, C.
Author full names: Jothimalar, T. (59008886400); Daniel Madan Raja, S. (59008067000); Bennila Thangammal, C. (56175435100)
Title: DEEP LEARNING APPROACH WITH STACKED AUTOENCODERS AND DEPTHWISE SEPARABLE CNNS FOR CASSAVA LEAF DISEASE DETECTION
Source title: Journal of Environmental Protection and Ecology
Affiliations: R.M.D. Engineering College, Kavaraipettai, India; Karunya Institute of Technology and Sciences, Coimbatore, India
Authors with affiliations: Jothimalar, T., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, R.M.D. Engineering College, Kavaraipettai, India; Daniel Madan Raja, S., School of Computer Science and Technology, Karunya Institute of Technology and Sciences, Coimbatore, India; Bennila Thangammal, C., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, R.M.D. Engineering College, Kavaraipettai, India
Abstract: Cassava, a primary crop in various regions worldwide, faces ongoing threats from diseases that can significantly affect crop yields and food security. This research introduces an innovative approach for automating the detection of cassava leaf diseases. We propose the use of an Enhanced Canny Edge Detector (ECED) in conjunction with Stacked Autoencoders (SAE) and Depthwise Separable Convolutional Neural Networks (DS-CNN) as a novel technique. The ECED is designed to enhance edge detection accuracy by addressing certain limitations of the traditional Canny edge detector. It incorporates adaptive thresholding, and noise reduction methods to generate more accurate and robust edge maps. The methodology consists of three essential components: DS-CNN for efficient feature extraction and classification, SAE for improved feature representation learning, and ECED for precise edge feature extraction. This combination harnesses both texture and structural information to enhance disease detection accuracy. To evaluate the effectiveness of this approach, we employ the comprehensive Cassava Leaf Disease Dataset, containing RGB images of cassava leaves categorised into three classes. These high-resolution images (512 × 512 pixels) originate from diverse agricultural fields in western Tamil Nadu, India. Experimental results demonstrate the outstanding performance of the integrated approach, achieving remarkable accuracy in the detection of cassava leaf diseases. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S., Chattopadhyay, Saumitra; A., Verma, Aditya; R.K., Chauhan, Rajeev Kumar; V., Kukreja, Vinay; R., Sharma, Rishabh
Author full names: Chattopadhyay, Saumitra (57268881400); Verma, Aditya (57223041283); Chauhan, Rajeev Kumar (58080845800); Kukreja, Vinay (49661773100); Sharma, Rishabh (57220725633)
Title: Leveraging Deep Learning's Potential: A CNN and LSTM Network-Based Severity Classification of Mustard Downy Mildew
Affiliations: Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; IIMT College of Engineering, Greater Noida, Greater Noida, India; Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Authors with affiliations: Chattopadhyay, Saumitra, Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Verma, Aditya, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, India; Chauhan, Rajeev Kumar, Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, IIMT College of Engineering, Greater Noida, Greater Noida, India; Kukreja, Vinay, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Sharma, Rishabh, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Abstract: Mustard downy mildew poses a huge threat to global farming of the mustards for an effective approach towards disease management, timely and accurate detection is important. This study presents a novel method based on Convolutional Neural Network (CNNs) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks that allows the classification of mustard downy mildew severity into five discrete levels. A high-resolution imaging dataset containing 12,000 images at different stages of disease progression was carefully created and used for model training and validation. The suggested model scored a highly satisfactory overall accuracy of 96.48%. Detailed analysis of precision, recall, and F1 score per class as presented in Table I suggested the model's predictive nature. It is important to note that the model had a high degree of accuracy at all levels of severity, indicating its ability to reduce false positives. The analysis of the confusion matrix. Gave a deep insight into the model's capacity to differentiate among severity levels, pointing out its practical applicability in agriculture environments. This is a breakthrough in the detection of mustard downy mildew since it develops an efficient automated tool for accurate severity classifications. Indeed, the success of this model creates opportunities for evidence-based crop management that is likely to lead towards sustainable agriculture and pave the way for more improvement in deep learning plant pathology. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Parveen, Suphiya (14627464200); Savita (58930368100); Ganguly, Saurav (57217395645)
Title: AI for Agro-Business in the Identification of Rice Diseases
Affiliations: JAIN (Deemed-to-be University), Bengaluru, India; Maharishi University of Information Technology, Lucknow, India; Presidency University Bangalore, Bengaluru, India
Authors with affiliations: Parveen, Suphiya, Department of Genetics, JAIN (Deemed-to-be University), Bengaluru, India; Savita, null, Maharishi School of Engineering & Technology, Maharishi University of Information Technology, Lucknow, India; Ganguly, Saurav, Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Presidency University Bangalore, Bengaluru, India
Abstract: Rice's quality and resistance to disease are crucial for agribusiness. Crop production must be increased using effective practises and tactics. The introduction of sophisticated artificial intelligence and machine learning methods has been especially beneficial to the area of agricultural innovation. By examining photos of leaves, agricultural fields, or seeds, these techniques have shown astoundingly high levels of success in diagnosing illnesses. In order to increase the production of rice, one of the main crops in the world, this research provides a thorough assessment with a precision agricultural emphasis. The research articles reviewed and analysed in this work use a variety of techniques for identifying crop diseases, evaluating the health of seedlings, and assessing grain quality. They were all published within the last eight years. The Web of Science and Scopus databases were used in experiments to extract data, which allowed for an analysis of research trends in rice disease diagnosis using artificial intelligence. This study includes worldwide trends, annual patterns, and country-specific citation data, offering insightful information to academics working in this area. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: N., Thapliyal, Nitin; M., Aeri, Manisha; A., Satyarthi, Abhishek; V., Kukreja, Vinay; R., Sharma, Rishabh
Author full names: Thapliyal, Nitin (57556100200); Aeri, Manisha (57216865924); Satyarthi, Abhishek (58999278100); Kukreja, Vinay (49661773100); Sharma, Rishabh (57220725633)
Title: Diagnosis of Plant Infection for Optimised Authomatic Health Monitoring System Using Vision Transformer Models
Affiliations: Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; IIMT College of Engineering, Greater Noida, Greater Noida, India; Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Authors with affiliations: Thapliyal, Nitin, Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Aeri, Manisha, Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Satyarthi, Abhishek, IIMT College of Engineering, Greater Noida, Greater Noida, India; Kukreja, Vinay, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Sharma, Rishabh, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Abstract: Mosaic Virus is highly responsible for the crop loss, especially the pepper, which is considered part of food crop, an essential aspect of world's agriculture. This work aims at automating the classification of disease severity level-related the Pepper Leaf Mosaic Virus Disease threshold through vision transformer (ViT) model to ensure a critical job. The classification of the severity is more often accompanied by a fairly significant amount of workload and arbitrariness, resulting in equipment innovation in most of the locations. The work applies ViT-based approaches with sufficient precision to appropriately classify a dataset, which contains 10,800 meticulously selected photographs. The present model obtained a commendable average accuracy of 97.25%, which shows that the model was able to detect even smaller differences between the classes of severity. The operational criteria that include the tale of the precision, recall, and F1-score highlight the model's ability to minimize to Feggsor false Positives with its ability to discriminate cases of viruses at different levels of the spectrum. The more advanced comparison charts made hand methodologies stand at the pinnacle in plant pathology studies. This study is not only beneficial in terms of illuminating the understanding about the Pepper Leaf Mosaic Virus but also gives farmers and researchers a transformative tool that could change the way disease control methods are used. Technologies AI that power ViT model are helping the agriculture industries throughout the world to implement sustainability and resiliency of the systems by providing responses in the right time and place in addressing viral infections. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Sakshi; C., Sharma, Chetan; S., Shamneesh, Sharma; T., Sharma, Tushar; S., Gochhait, Saikat
Author full names: Sakshi (60003770400); Sharma, Chetan (57210514864); Shamneesh, Sharma (55491693900); Sharma, Tushar (57212942625); Gochhait, Saikat (57202706369)
Title: Green Intelligence: A Sequential CNN Odyssey in Mustard Leaf Disease Detection
Affiliations: Sharda University, Greater Noida, India; upGrad Education Private Limited, Mumbai, India; Lovely Professional University, Phagwara, India; Symbiosis Institute of Digital and Telecom Management, Pune, India; Samara State Medical University, Samara, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Sakshi, null, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Sharda University, Greater Noida, India; Sharma, Chetan, upGrad Education Private Limited, Mumbai, India; Shamneesh, Sharma, upGrad Education Private Limited, Mumbai, India; Sharma, Tushar, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Lovely Professional University, Phagwara, India; Gochhait, Saikat, Symbiosis Institute of Digital and Telecom Management, Pune, India, Samara State Medical University, Samara, Russian Federation
Abstract: Mustard plants are a crucial agricultural commodity for food and oil production. However, they are frequently vulnerable to various diseases that can substantially reduce crop yield. Early identification and diagnosis of these illnesses are essential for efficient management and control, ensuring sustainable production and agricultural output continuity. This research presents a new method for categorizing mustard leaf diseases using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The study utilizes sophisticated machine learning algorithms to differentiate between healthy and diseased mustard leaves, which is crucial for maintaining agricultural output and guaranteeing food security. The study involves training CNN architectures - Sequential CNN, ResNet-50, VGG, and AlexNet - on a meticulously curated dataset comprising images of healthy and diseased mustard leaves. The classifier's effectiveness is validated through comprehensive testing, demonstrating significant precision, recall, and F1-score advancements over conventional methods. This approach provides an efficient tool for disease detection in mustard crops and contributes to sustainable agricultural practices, aligning with the global goal of food security and environmental sustainability. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: V., Kukreja, Vinay; S.K., Vikrant, Sharma K.; R., Sharma, Rishabh
Author full names: Kukreja, Vinay (49661773100); Vikrant, Sharma K. (56785043200); Sharma, Rishabh (57220725633)
Title: Utilizing a Hybrid CNN-LSTM Model for Automated Severity Classification of Rice Panicle Blast Disease
Affiliations: Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India
Authors with affiliations: Kukreja, Vinay, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Vikrant, Sharma K., Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, India; Sharma, Rishabh, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Abstract: Rice panicle blast is a globally prevalent and detrimental disease that impacts rice cultivation on a large scale. It poses a threat to both the quantity and quality of the rice they obtain. Our work proposes a novel approach utilizing a Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)-Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) deep learning (DL) model to accurately assess the severity of a rice panicle blast. This facilitates the resolution of the issue. This novel approach aims to overcome the limitations of traditional approaches to illness diagnosis. These methods are frequently incorrect and inefficient due to their requirement for extensive effort. For this research, we developed and meticulously trained a hybrid model utilizing a robust dataset of over 15,000 distinctly labeled images. These photographs depicted several stages and issues related to blast illness in rice panicles. Our model is unique due to its utilization of the salient features of CNN for spatial localization in images, and LSTM networks for efficient temporal information processing. This union creates a powerful tool for accurately categorizing illnesses. The CNN-LSTM model achieved a high accuracy rate of 97.97% in correctly predicting the severity of a disease within the range of one to five levels. The model maintained a consistently high level of accuracy, recall, and F1-score across all groups. This demonstrates the robustness and reliability of it. Our model surpasses traditional methods. It remains consistent and precise, demonstrating significant advancements in the field of agricultural disease categorization. This study not only provides an effective method for testing rice panicle blast, but also opens up new opportunities for the utilization of intelligent machinery in agriculture. This approach demonstrates the efficacy of DL techniques in enhancing disease management, resulting in increased agricultural yield and environmentally sustainable farming practices. Subsequent research endeavors may endeavor to employ this approach on a broader range of plant species and diseases. Utilizing advanced computer technologies will further enhance global agricultural practices. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Yan, Xiaolu; Q., Ma, Qin; Q., Feng, Quanlong
Title: A method for detecting the number of wheat ears based on the improved YOLOX model
Affiliations: China Agricultural University, Beijing, China; China Agricultural University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Yan, Xiaolu, China Agricultural University, Beijing, China; Ma, Qin, China Agricultural University, Beijing, China; Feng, Quanlong, China Agricultural University, Beijing, China
Abstract: Ear count serves as a crucial parameter for estimating wheat yield, holding great significance in crop phenotypic parameter calculations, yield predictions and wheat ear density management. To accurately determine the number of wheat ears, this study utilized the Global Wheat Head Detection 2021 dataset, and introduced a wheat ear counting method based on the improved YOLOX model. An attention mechanism was integrated into the feature extraction network to bolster the semantic information of the feature map. This enhancement aimed to improve the capability of effectively detecting wheat ears. By using GIoU loss to optimize the loss function, the positioning accuracy of bounding box was improved. Experimental results show that, compared with other models, the improved YOLOX model has significantly improved the detection effect of different targets. Among them, the precision of the improved YOLOX model is 97.24%, the average precision is 94.15%, the accuracy is 99.76%, and the log average miss detection rate is 0.25. This study provides a reliable method for precision wheat ear identification, offering valuable applications in high-throughput investigation of wheat ear traits. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: M.H., Ashfaq, Muhammad Hasnain; I.M., Khan, Imran Mohammad; A.A., Alzahrani, Abdulrahman Ahmed; M.U., Tariq, Muhammad Usman; H., Khan, Humera; A., Ghani, Anwar
Author full names: Ashfaq, Muhammad Hasnain (57223453248); Khan, Imran Mohammad (58592356700); Alzahrani, Abdulrahman Ahmed (58028179300); Tariq, Muhammad Usman (56542764000); Khan, Humera (56304198600); Ghani, Anwar (55366311900)
Title: Accurate Wheat Yield Prediction Using Machine Learning and Climate-NDVI Data Fusion
Affiliations: International Islamic University, Islamabad, Islamabad, Pakistan; University of Jeddah, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia; Abu Dhabi University, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates; Northern Border University, Arar, Saudi Arabia; International Islamic University, Islamabad, Islamabad, Pakistan; Jeju National University, Jeju, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Ashfaq, Muhammad Hasnain, Department of Software Engineering, International Islamic University, Islamabad, Islamabad, Pakistan; Khan, Imran Mohammad, Department of Computer Science, International Islamic University, Islamabad, Islamabad, Pakistan; Alzahrani, Abdulrahman Ahmed, Department of Information Systems and Technology, University of Jeddah, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia; Tariq, Muhammad Usman, and Information System, Abu Dhabi University, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates; Khan, Humera, Department of Information Systems, Northern Border University, Arar, Saudi Arabia; Ghani, Anwar, Department of Computer Science, International Islamic University, Islamabad, Islamabad, Pakistan, Big Data Research Center, Jeju National University, Jeju, South Korea
Abstract: Due to exponential population growth, climate change, and an increasing demand for food, there is an unprecedented need for a timely, precise, and dependable assessment of crop yield on a large scale. Wheat, a staple crop worldwide, requires accurate and prompt prediction of its output for global food security. Traditionally, the development of empirical models for crop yield forecasting has relied on climate data, satellite data, or a combination of both. Despite the enhanced performance achieved by integrating satellite and climate data, the contributions from various sources (Climate, Soil, Socioeconomic, and Remote sensing) remain unclear. The lack of well-defined comparisons between the performance of regression-based approaches and different Machine Learning (ML) methods in yield prediction necessitates further investigation. This study addresses the gaps by combining data from multiple sources to forecast wheat yield in the Multan region in the Punjab province of Pakistan. The findings are compared to the benchmark provided by Crop Report Services (CRS) Punjab, with three widely used ML techniques (support vector machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO)) by integrating publicly available data within the GEE (Google Earth Engine) platform, including climate, satellite, soil properties, and spatial information data to develop alternative empirical models for yield prediction using data from 2017 to 2022, selecting the best attribute subset related to crop output. The district-level simulated yield data set was analyzed with three ML models (SVM, RF, and LASSO) as a function of seasonal weather, satellite, and soil. The results indicate that combining all datasets using three ML algorithms achieves better yield prediction performance (R2: 0.74-0.88). Incorporating spatial information and other properties into benchmark models can improve the prediction from 0.08 to 0.12. Random forest outperformed the competitor models with a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 0.05 q/ha and R2 of 0.88. Comparative analysis shows that random forest with 97% and SVM with 93% yielded better results in the study area. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Sun, Cuimin; M., Zhang, Menghua; M., Zhou, Muchen; X., Zhou, Xingzhi
Author full names: Sun, Cuimin (57155480000); Zhang, Menghua (57473444000); Zhou, Muchen (58261084500); Zhou, Xingzhi (58671779600)
Title: An Improved Transformer Network With Multi-Scale Convolution for Weed Identification in Sugarcane Field
Affiliations: Guangxi University, Nanning, China; Guangxi University, Nanning, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Cuimin, Guangxi University, Nanning, China; Zhang, Menghua, Guangxi University, Nanning, China; Zhou, Muchen, Guangxi University, Nanning, China; Zhou, Xingzhi, Guangxi University, Nanning, China
Abstract: Automated weeding equipment is urgently needed to deal with weeds in farmlands in the context of the rapid development of Intelligent Agriculture. A system for accurately identifying crops and weeds in images is crucial component of automated weeding equipment. However, in the field environment, crops and weeds grow intertwined, and weeds are very similar to sugarcane leaves, making it difficult to accurately segment crops, weeds, and their boundaries from images. In this paper, we proposed a novel network that fully utilizes low-level semantic information to accurately segment crops and weeds in images, improving the accuracy of crop and weed segmentation while reducing the need for training weight parameters and improving speed in the prediction stage. Specifically, we made three important modifications for crop and weed identification. First, a Multi-scale Feature Extraction and Fusion module (MFEF) was designed to capture abundant low-level semantic feature information. Afterward, we introduce a Global Response Normalization (GRN) block to select more useful feature information. Finally, a series of residual attention transformer layers are designed to transmit the long-range dependency information extracted between layers. Numerous experimental results confirmed that our proposed network achieved excellent performance in segmenting sugarcane and weed images. Specifically, (1) the mean accuracy and, Mean Intersection of Union (MIoU) reached 96.97% and 94.13%, respectively, (2) the training parameters of the model have been reduced by more than 25%, improving the Frames Per Second (FPS) value of the prediction process, and (3) is also effective on the publicly available BoniRob Dataset, indicating that the proposed model has considerable generalization ability. This study provides an accurate weed identification map and has reference significance for subsequent systems as mechanical weeding equipment. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: R., Rashid, Rubina; W., Aslam, Waqar; R., Aziz, Romana; G.N., Aldehim, Ghadah Nasser
Author full names: Rashid, Rubina (57222319865); Aslam, Waqar (34972616300); Aziz, Romana (57970017200); Aldehim, Ghadah Nasser (57977814800)
Title: An Early and Smart Detection of Corn Plant Leaf Diseases Using IoT and Deep Learning Multi-Models
Affiliations: Government Post Graduate College for Women, Bahawalnagar, Pakistan; The Islamia University of Bahawalpur, Bahawalpur, Pakistan; Princess Nourah Bint Abdulrahman University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Rashid, Rubina, Department of Computer Science and IT, Government Post Graduate College for Women, Bahawalnagar, Pakistan; Aslam, Waqar, Department of Information Security, The Islamia University of Bahawalpur, Bahawalpur, Pakistan; Aziz, Romana, Department of Information Systems, Princess Nourah Bint Abdulrahman University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Aldehim, Ghadah Nasser, Department of Information Systems, Princess Nourah Bint Abdulrahman University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Plant leaf diseases have various causes, leading to severe disorders. The early and accurate detection and classification of these diseases are fundamental for fostering healthy crop production. In recent years, smart agricultural systems have garnered significant attention due to their capability to enhance efficiency by deploying sensor networks and Internet of Things (IoT) devices that collect and analyze environmental data. However, traditional plant disease detection methods are manual, time-consuming, and often need help handling the data's complexity and dynamism. These manual methods do not use heterogeneous data to make better decisions. Corn holds significant importance yet it faces numerous diseases that include main three diseases such as blight, common rust, and grey leaf spot. The advancement of computer technology has led to a pivotal focus on corn leaf diseases classification application based on deep learning. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have revealed remarkable achievements within Precision Agriculture (PA) due to their ability to enhance information. To this end, this work introduces a CNN-based architecture, the Multi-Model Fusion Network (MMF-Net). Its primary objective is to classify diseases within the realm of PA. MMF-Net integrates multi-contextual features using RL-block and PL-blocks 1 & 2, thus effectively combining different model streams trained on heterogeneous data. The RL-block uses spatial range to process coarse grained images to convolve the local context, while PL-block 1 extracts fine-grained global context by expanding the perceptual area of images. PL-block 2 deals with real-life environmental parameters as features. The extracted features are syndicated using multiple classifiers that ensemble three individual blocks at the decision level to improve the accuracy. After fusion, it uses adaptively the majority voting scheme to generate the final decision probability score of the base model. Multiple experiments are conducted involving the corn leaf diseases dataset and a real-life numerical dataset, generating an impressive 99.23% accuracy in the classification of corn leaf diseases. Overall, MMF-Net provides a promising and smart solution to identify plant leaf diseases in PA effectively. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: A., Corceiro, Ana; N., Pereira, Nuno; K., Alibabaei, Khadijeh; P.D., Gaspar, P. D.
Author full names: Corceiro, Ana (57476420000); Pereira, Nuno (57216361399); Alibabaei, Khadijeh (57194767293); Gaspar, P. D. (57419570900)
Title: Leveraging Machine Learning for Weed Management and Crop Enhancement: Vineyard Flora Classification
Affiliations: Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal; Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal; Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal; Karlsruher Institut für Technologie, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Corceiro, Ana, Department of Electromechanical Engineering, Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal, Centre for Mechanical and Aerospace Science and Technologies (C-MAST), Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal; Pereira, Nuno, Department of Computer Science, Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal; Alibabaei, Khadijeh, Karlsruher Institut für Technologie, Karlsruhe, Germany; Gaspar, P. D., Department of Electromechanical Engineering, Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal, Centre for Mechanical and Aerospace Science and Technologies (C-MAST), Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha, Portugal
Abstract: The global population’s rapid growth necessitates a 70% increase in agricultural production, posing challenges exacerbated by weed infestation and herbicide drawbacks. To address this, machine learning (ML) models, particularly convolutional neural networks (CNNs), are employed in precision agriculture (PA) for weed detection. This study focuses on testing CNN architectures for image classification tasks using the PyTorch framework, emphasizing hyperparameter optimization. Four groups of experiments were carried out: the first one trained all the PyTorch architectures, followed by the creation of a baseline, the evaluation of a new and extended dataset in the best models, and finally, the test phase was conducted using a web application developed for this purpose. Of 80 CNN sub-architectures tested, the MaxVit, ShuffleNet, and EfficientNet models stand out, achieving a maximum accuracy of 96.0%, 99.3%, and 99.3%, respectively, for the first test phase of PyTorch classification architectures. In addition, EfficientNet_B1 and EfficientNet_B5 stood out compared to all other models. During experiment 3, with a new dataset, both models achieved a high accuracy of 95.13% and 94.83%, respectively. Furthermore, in experiment 4, both EfficientNet_B1 and EfficientNet_B5 achieved a maximum accuracy of 96.15%, the highest one. ML models can help to automate crop problem detection, promote organic farming, optimize resource use, aid precision farming, reduce waste, boost efficiency, and contribute to a greener, sustainable agricultural future. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: J.U.M., Akbar, Jalal Uddin Md; S.F., Kamarulzaman, Syafiq Fauzi; A.J.M., Muzahid, Abu Jafar Md; M.A., Rahman, Md Arafatur; M., Uddin, Mueen
Author full names: Akbar, Jalal Uddin Md (57478065100); Kamarulzaman, Syafiq Fauzi (54393365400); Muzahid, Abu Jafar Md (57221741096); Rahman, Md Arafatur (55457938100); Uddin, Mueen (42062605100)
Title: A Comprehensive Review on Deep Learning Assisted Computer Vision Techniques for Smart Greenhouse Agriculture
Affiliations: Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Tickle College of Engineering, Knoxville, United States; University of Wolverhampton, Wolverhampton, United Kingdom; University of Doha for Science and Technology, Doha, Qatar
Authors with affiliations: Akbar, Jalal Uddin Md, Faculty of Computing, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Kamarulzaman, Syafiq Fauzi, Faculty of Computing, Universiti Malaysia Pahang Al-Sultan Abdullah, Pekan, Malaysia; Muzahid, Abu Jafar Md, Department of Mechanics, Tickle College of Engineering, Knoxville, United States; Rahman, Md Arafatur, School of Mathematics and Computer Science, University of Wolverhampton, Wolverhampton, United Kingdom; Uddin, Mueen, College of Computing and Information Technology, University of Doha for Science and Technology, Doha, Qatar
Abstract: With the escalating global challenges of food security and resource sustainability, innovative solutions like deep learning and computer vision are transforming agricultural practices by enabling data-driven decision-making. This paper provides a focused review of recent advancements in deep learning-enabled computer vision techniques tailored specifically for greenhouse environments. First, deep learning and computer vision fundamentals are briefly introduced. Over 100 studies from 2020 to date are then comprehensively reviewed in which these technologies were applied within greenhouses for growth monitoring, disease detection, yield estimation, and other tasks. The techniques, datasets, models, and overall performance results reported in the literature are analyzed. Tables and figures showcase real-world implementations and results synthesized from current research. Key challenges are also outlined related to aspects like model adaptability, lack of sufficient labeled greenhouse data, computational constraints, the need for multi-modal sensor fusion, and other areas needing further investigation. Future trends and prospects are discussed to provide guidance for researchers exploring computer vision in the niche greenhouse domain. By condensing prior work and elucidating the state-of-the-art, this timely review aims to promote continued progress in smart greenhouse agriculture. The focused analysis, specifically on greenhouse environments, fills a gap compared to previous agricultural surveys. Overall, this paper highlights the immense potential of computer vision and deep learning in driving the emergence of data-driven, smart greenhouse farming worldwide. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: H., Cheng, Hebin; H., Li, Heming; J., Lian, Jian
Title: UAV-based Anomaly Detection via a novel Spatial-Temporal Transformer for Precision Agriculture
Affiliations: Shandong Management University, Jinan, China
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, Hebin, Shandong Management University, Jinan, China; Li, Heming, Shandong Management University, Jinan, China; Lian, Jian, Shandong Management University, Jinan, China
Abstract: Low altitude security has gained widespread concern for its applications, e.g., cropland monitoring. In this work, an Internet of Drones architecture was firstly presented for low altitude scenarios. Within the presented framework, each drone can communicate with each other and the ground base stations while traveling along a fixed route. Since anomalous activities can significantly affect the normal operation of the Internet of Drones, it becomes critical to differentiate the normal surroundings from the abnormal surroundings around the drones. On the other hand, the vision transformer-based deep learning models have exhibited their superiority even over the convolutional neural network-based architectures due to the adoption of global receptive field. Bearing the above-mentioned issue in mind, we propose a novel deep learning pipeline by leveraging the vision transformer model for anomaly detection in the low altitude context. The sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, and F1 score of the proposed approach on a manually-collected dataset are 91.2%, 92.5%, 92.2%, and 93.7%, respectively. In addition, the experimental results demonstrate that the proposed deep learning pipeline can yield a promising outcome over the state-of-the-art algorithms. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: R., Rajora, Ricky; A., Rajora, Aarju; P., Dhiman, Payal; B., Sharma, Bhanu
Author full names: Rajora, Ricky (58194349200); Rajora, Aarju (58683211800); Dhiman, Payal (59941087800); Sharma, Bhanu (57212491675)
Title: Advanced Disease Classification of Rutabaga plant using CNN-SVM: Enhancing Early Detection and Precision Agriculture
Affiliations: Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Chandigarh Engineering College, Mohali, India
Authors with affiliations: Rajora, Ricky, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India; Rajora, Aarju, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Chandigarh Engineering College, Mohali, India; Dhiman, Payal, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Chandigarh Engineering College, Mohali, India; Sharma, Bhanu, Chitkara University, Punjab, Rajpura, India
Abstract: This study introduces an exhaustive classification system for the detection of rutabaga plant diseases is presented in this research. Clubroot, Powdery Mildew, Downy Mildew, Aphid-Transmitted Viruses, Rust Diseases, and Blackleg (Phoma lingam) are particularly highlighted. The model's outstanding performance is shown by its accuracy result (94.38-96.09 %), recall (93.10%-96.22%), and F1-Score (95.23%). Measures like these prove that the model is accurate and useful for detecting diseases. Increasing the model's practical use, the assistance percentage numbers give light to the dataset's distribution across various disease categories. The weighted average demonstrates the model's endurance across many classes, with a total accuracy of 95.24 %. At the same time, micro and macro averages provide thorough assessments of its efficiency. Utilizing state-of-the-art technologies like CNN and SVM, this research presenting a robust model for rutabaga classification. It is contributing to precision agriculture. Since the findings provide a way for targeted treatments and early disease detection, this is very significant for agricultural methods. The improved agricultural yield and increased food security on a worldwide scale are the results of this measure. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: X., Meng, Xintong; Y., Wang, Yiqun; G., Yang, Genjian; K., Zhang, Ke; Y., Zhang, Yuxin; W., Chen, Wenbai
Title: NanoDet-BiFPN: A Lightweight Wheat Ear Detection Network
Affiliations: Beijing Information Science & Technology University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Meng, Xintong, College of Automation, Beijing Information Science & Technology University, Beijing, China; Wang, Yiqun, College of Automation, Beijing Information Science & Technology University, Beijing, China; Yang, Genjian, College of Automation, Beijing Information Science & Technology University, Beijing, China; Zhang, Ke, College of Automation, Beijing Information Science & Technology University, Beijing, China; Zhang, Yuxin, College of Automation, Beijing Information Science & Technology University, Beijing, China; Chen, Wenbai, College of Automation, Beijing Information Science & Technology University, Beijing, China
Abstract: Wheat, as a major staple crop extensively cultivated worldwide, supports the food needs of one-third of the global population. Its healthy cultivation not only concerns national food security but also profoundly affects the regulation and trade patterns of international food resources. To assess wheat planting density and predict yields, this study designs a lightweight wheat detection network based on NanoDet. The network encoding process incorporates Ghost convolution, which introduces more feature maps during the convolution process using fewer parameters and computing resources, thereby enhancing the network's computational efficiency and operational speed. Additionally, a Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network (BiFPN) is employed to optimize the information transfer and fusion between feature layers, enhancing the model's capability to process multi-scale features, and further improving performance and efficiency. Experiments conducted on the public Global Wheat Head Dataset (GWHD) show that the model improves detection accuracy and speed without significantly increasing the size of the weight model file. The average detection precision of wheat heads reached 84.3%, with a detection speed of up to 14.3ms per frame, and the weight model file size is approximately 4.3MB. This rapid inference speed and minimal model size provide significant support for embedded devices, offering robust backing for the field application of intelligent agriculture. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: C., Lu, Chengwen; M., Li, Mengmeng; X., Xiu, Xiaolong; J., Long, Jiang; C., Zhang, Congcong
Author full names: Lu, Chengwen (59320864500); Li, Mengmeng (48761446900); Xiu, Xiaolong (57272304300); Long, Jiang (57765412000); Zhang, Congcong (58919627400)
Title: Integration of CNN and Transformer for Regularized Extraction of Agricultural Parcels from High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images
Affiliations: Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Spatial Data Mining and Information Sharing, Fuzhou, China; Fujian Geological Remote Sensing and Geographic Information Service Center, Fuzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Chengwen, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Spatial Data Mining and Information Sharing, Fuzhou, China; Li, Mengmeng, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Spatial Data Mining and Information Sharing, Fuzhou, China; Xiu, Xiaolong, Fujian Geological Remote Sensing and Geographic Information Service Center, Fuzhou, China; Long, Jiang, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Spatial Data Mining and Information Sharing, Fuzhou, China; Zhang, Congcong, Ministry of Education Key Laboratory of Spatial Data Mining and Information Sharing, Fuzhou, China
Abstract: Agricultural parcels are the fundamental spatial units of precision agricultural practices. However, in southern regions, the parcels tend to be small, structurally complex, and fragmented, posing challenges for precise extraction using existing convolutional neural network (CNNs) based on deep learning. To address these issues, we introduced a novel neural network model, i.e., CLCFormer, which combines CNN and Swin-Transformer. This model leverages the strengths of CNN in capturing fine-grained spatial details and the ability of Transformer in extracting global semantic features. We introduced three distinct modules to refine the learning of spatial features, enhance the accuracy of parcel extraction in mountainous and hilly regions, and mitigate the boundary blurriness caused by occluded objects. Finally, we employed a post-processing method to achieve regularized parcel extraction. Our study was tested on GF-2 high-resolution remote sensing datasets from Nanping and Fuzhou, Fujian Province, China. Our proposed method achieved a prediction precision of 86.68% and a recall rate of 85.3% on the Nanping test set, and maintaining a transfer precision of 85.67% on the Fuzhou dataset. Compared to other advanced parcel extraction models, our method demonstrates the highest performance. Moreover, the extracted parcels have the highest consistency with the actual distribution patterns of agricultural parcels. We provided a practical approach for precise extraction of agricultural parcels information at the parcel scale. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: R.H., Chowdhury, Rafi Hassan; S., Ahmed, Sabbir
Author full names: Chowdhury, Rafi Hassan (59940309000); Ahmed, Sabbir (57223210153)
Title: MangoLeafViT: Leveraging Lightweight Vision Transformer with Runtime Augmentation for Efficient Mango Leaf Disease Classification
Affiliations: Islamic University of Technology, Gazipur, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Chowdhury, Rafi Hassan, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Islamic University of Technology, Gazipur, Bangladesh; Ahmed, Sabbir, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Islamic University of Technology, Gazipur, Bangladesh
Abstract: Ensuring food safety is critical due to its profound impact on public health, economic stability, and global supply chains. Cultivation of Mango, a major agricultural product in several South Asian countries, faces high financial losses due to different diseases, affecting various aspects of the entire supply chain. While deep learning-based methods have been explored for mango leaf disease classification, there remains a gap in designing solutions that are computationally efficient and compatible with low-end devices. In this work, we propose a lightweight Vision Transformer-based pipeline with a self-attention mechanism to classify mango leaf diseases, achieving state-of-the-art performance with minimal computational overhead. Our approach leverages global attention to capture intricate patterns among disease types and incorporates runtime augmentation for enhanced performance. Evaluation on the MangoLeafBD dataset demonstrates a 99.43% accuracy, outperforming existing methods in terms of model size, parameter count, and FLOPs count. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: S.G., Akther, Syeda Gulnaj; A.H.M.S., Islam, Ashraful H.M.Saiful; E.J., Muna, Effat Jahan; J.J., Tasmi, Jannat Jahan
Author full names: Akther, Syeda Gulnaj (59964156500); Islam, Ashraful H.M.Saiful (57189643577); Muna, Effat Jahan (59963030200); Tasmi, Jannat Jahan (59963712800)
Title: AI Meets Agriculture: Advanced Rice Yield Forecasting Based on Historical Data using Machine Learning Approaches
Affiliations: Sylhet Engineering College, Sylhet, Bangladesh; University of Regina, Regina, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Akther, Syeda Gulnaj, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Sylhet Engineering College, Sylhet, Bangladesh; Islam, Ashraful H.M.Saiful, Department of Computer Science, University of Regina, Regina, Canada; Muna, Effat Jahan, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Sylhet Engineering College, Sylhet, Bangladesh; Tasmi, Jannat Jahan, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Sylhet Engineering College, Sylhet, Bangladesh
Abstract: Despite the global importance of agriculture, inefficient practices persist, particularly in poorer regions. A big obstacle to increasing agricultural outputs is the inefficiency of conventional methods and the absence of accurate instruments for predicting crop yields. While various machine learning techniques have been used by several researchers to forecast yields, the difficulty lies in developing models that adequately account for regional nuances. To overcome this problem, this study proposed a novel machine learning-based approach for crop yield prediction focused on the Sylhet region, Bangladesh with a large unique dataset named "EcoRiceDynamics (1971-2021)."Four models - Linear Regression, Random Forest, Gradient Boosted, and K-Nearest Neighbors are evaluated to improve forecast precision. Performance was measured using the R2 value and error reduction metrics. Our results show that the Gradient Boosted model achieved the highest R2 value of 95% and MAE 6.71%, indicating its superior fit to the dataset. However, the Random Forest model excelled in minimizing prediction errors by 6.37% with R2 value of 94.1%. Random Forest reduces prediction errors effectively, while Gradient Boosted explains variance better. Incorporating these models into agricultural systems could enhance decision-making and crop yields in regions like Sylhet. This study highlights the potential of machine learning in advancing agricultural sustainability on yield estimation. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning for Potato Leaf Disease Classification
Affiliations: visie.tech, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Khulna University, Khulna, Bangladesh; Khulna University of Engineering and Technology, Khulna, Bangladesh; Ahsanullah University of Science and Technology, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Paul, Laboni, visie.tech, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Ali, Ferdous Bin, visie.tech, Dhaka, Bangladesh, Ict Cell, Khulna University, Khulna, Bangladesh; Deb Mohalder, Rahul, ; Rabita, Sayra Tasmin, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Khulna University of Engineering and Technology, Khulna, Bangladesh; Sakif, S. M.Nabil, Ict Cell, Khulna University, Khulna, Bangladesh; Islam, Md Hasibul, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Ahsanullah University of Science and Technology, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Khan, Md Al Mamun, visie.tech, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Abstract: Potato crops, vital to global food security, are often jeopardized by numerous foliar diseases, including late blight, early blight, and bacterial leaf spot. If untreated, these illnesses can lead to substantial yield losses and negatively impact agricultural output. Conventional disease diagnosis methods, which frequently depend on expert manual inspection, are both time-consuming and labor-intensive, as well as prone to human errors. Recent improvements in deep learning-based image classification approaches have shown considerable potential in automating the identification of plant diseases, offering a scalable and more dependable alternative to manual inspections. In this research, we proposed a Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning methodology for the classification of potato leaf diseases using two publicly available potato leaf datasets. Our model attained an accuracy of 99.46% with a loss of 0.013957 and an accuracy of 98.79% with a loss of 0.096844. These results indicate the potential of self-supervised contrastive learning in agricultural disease detection, offering a scalable and efficient solution for real-world disease classification with minimal reliance on labeled data. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Deep Learning and CNN-Based Approach for Efficient Detection of Potato Leaf Diseases
Source title: IEEE Asia-Pacific Conference on Geoscience, Electronics and Remote Sensing Technology, AGERS

Abstract: Potato is a maj or food crop worldwide, providing essential nutrients to millions. However, various diseases can severely affect potato crops, leading to reduced yield and quality. Early disease detection is crucial for effective disease management and control. This study presents a deep learning-based approach using CNN to autonomously diagnose potato leaf diseases. The model leverages the Plant Village dataset, which contains images of potato leaves in both healthy and diseased states. The proposed method demonstrates high accuracy in identifying multiple potato leaf diseases, offering promising results for application in precision agriculture. By utilizing CNN s, the model effectively detects and classifies disease symptoms, providing a reliable tool for early intervention in agricultural practices. The approach's potential impact on improving crop yield and minimizing losses due to diseases is highlighted, making it a significant contribution to smart farming techniques. The study underscores the importance of deep learning in modern agricultural practices and its role in enhancing disease management strategies. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: O.M., Ayman, Omar Mohamed; M.E., Gamal, Mosaab Emad; M., Elsayed Atwa, Mohamed; Y., Khaled, Yassin; N.G., El-Din Saad, Noha Gamal
Author full names: Ayman, Omar Mohamed (59258527500); Gamal, Mosaab Emad (59893576400); Elsayed Atwa, Mohamed (59893576500); Khaled, Yassin (59894322100); El-Din Saad, Noha Gamal (57666758100)
Title: Exploiting Machine Learning and Remote Sensing for Precision Crop Mapping in Africa
Affiliations: Nile University, El Sheikh Zayed, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Ayman, Omar Mohamed, Computer Science Program School of ITCS, Nile University, El Sheikh Zayed, Egypt; Gamal, Mosaab Emad, Computer Science Program School of ITCS, Nile University, El Sheikh Zayed, Egypt; Elsayed Atwa, Mohamed, Computer Science Program School of ITCS, Nile University, El Sheikh Zayed, Egypt; Khaled, Yassin, Computer Science Program School of ITCS, Nile University, El Sheikh Zayed, Egypt; El-Din Saad, Noha Gamal, Computer Science Program School of ITCS, Nile University, El Sheikh Zayed, Egypt
Abstract: As the global population continues to grow, the demand for food intensifies, making precision agriculture essential for enhancing productivity and resource efficiency. A critical component of precision agriculture is accurate crop mapping, which enables optimized resource allocation and better yield prediction. This study focuses on developing a machine learning-based predictive model for crop mapping using multispectral remote sensing data from the Senegalese groundnut basin. The dataset, collected via Sentinel-2 satellites, includes optical bands and vegetation indices over four time periods in 2023. After preprocessing and addressing class imbalance through data augmentation and SMOTE, several machine learning models were evaluated, with Random Forest emerging as the most effective. The results show a significant improvement in classification accuracy, particularly for underrepresented crop types, with the Random Forest model achieving 93.57% accuracy after SMOTE, compared to 57.43% before SMOTE. The outcomes of this research extend beyond technological advancements, contributing to environmental sustainability by enabling more precise resource use, reducing waste, and minimizing the environmental impact of agricultural practices. Furthermore, this type of crop mapping supports food security by helping farmers optimize yields and manage crops more effectively, directly benefiting communities reliant on agriculture. The integration of machine learning and remote sensing in precision agriculture has the potential to foster a more resilient and sustainable agricultural system globally. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: EfficientNetB0-Based Deep Learning Approach for Crop Growth Stage Classification
Affiliations: Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Priya, Bairi Sai, Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India; Ram, Ramishetti Lohith Sai, Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India; Manojkumar, Madapathi, Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India; Vennam, Tharun Reddy, Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India; Murthy, V. N.L.N., Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India; Regulwar, Ganesh B., Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: This paper thoroughly examines the employment of the highly potent EfficientNetB0 convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture for image-based growth phase classification of maize crops, aiming to advance precision agriculture by automating key management and monitoring activities. This project seeks to increase agricultural productivity and efficiency through the application of modern deep-learning algorithms. The methodology begins with the preprocessing of a comprehensive dataset of maize crop images. These images are resized to 224x224 pixels to ensure uniformity and standardization across the dataset, which is crucial for the effective training of the CNN. Pixel values are also standardized to optimize the model's preparation phase. Transfer learning is employed, utilizing pre-trained ImageNet weights, which facilitates faster convergence and improves predictive accuracy by leveraging the vast amount of knowledge already embedded in the EfficientNetB0 model. EfficientNetB0 serves as the foundational architecture due to its balanced trade-off between efficiency and accuracy. The model's design includes dropout regularization techniques to mitigate overfitting, which is essential for maintaining generalizability to unseen data. Dense layers are incorporated for hierarchical feature extraction, while global average pooling is used for feature aggregation, reducing the risk of overfitting and maintaining model efficiency. Batch normalization is used to provide consistent learning rates across all layers of the model and to expedite and stabilize the training process. TensorFlow and Keras, powerful deep learning frameworks, are utilized to build and train the model. The classification results demonstrate the model's capability to accurately distinguish between different growth stages of maize crops based solely on images. This accuracy is validated through various benchmarks that assess the model's performance during both the training and validation phases, focusing on metrics such as loss and accuracy. The model's proficiency in accurately predicting maize crop growth stages is further evidenced by its performance on an unseen test set, showcasing its potential for scaling in agricultural monitoring systems. By integrating advanced deep learning techniques, this research contributes significantly to the field of agricultural technology, optimizing production management practices and enhancing yield prediction accuracy. While the primary focus has been on maize, the model shows promise for application to a broader range of crops. Future improvements may include refining the dataset and developing more sophisticated neural networks to achieve even higher accuracy across diverse crops and agricultural environments. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
